loans.name: Totorilla Group

texts.es:
The Totorilla Community Bank started 6 months ago and actually has 2 cycles and 19 members. The bank has the name of the community where all of its members live. Totorilla is a small valley where most of the population dedicates themselves to agriculture. Their lands produce coriander, spinach, cabbage, lettuce, and alfalfa. They are also dedicated to raise small farm animals and cattle in small proportion.

The members do different activities like mototaxi service, agriculture, raising farm animals and selling groceries, fruits, propane gas and beverages. In Yolanda's, Olga"s and Pecina's case they work in the agricultural fields; something that they learned since young and presently they work together with their husbands. They cultivate spinach, coriander, cabbage, lettuce and alfalfa and also raise small farm animals and cattle in small proportion. They sell their own products at wholesale and retail in a local public market named Nery G. Zarate.

The members need loans in different amounts, some amounts are 300 soles(Peruvian currency), 600 soles, 900 soles being a total of 8600 soles in loans for the Totorilla Community Bank. The money will be invested in buying seeds,fertilizers, rice, sugar, noodles, milk, propane gas, tires for a motorcycle and also to buy "cuy" ( a typical Peruvian animal) to be raised. The members are also learning parenting skills, how to raise, feed, and educate their children, and how to be responsible citizens. Their dreams are all different some want their children to become professionals, some want them to own their farm, land, and home and some of them dream of buying a car someday.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer

El Banco Comunal Totorilla se inició hace 6 meses y actualmente tiene 2 ciclos y 19socias, y lleva el nombre D. la comunidad, D. donD. son todos los socios. Totorilla es un pequeño valle donD. su población se dedica a la agricultura, sus tierras producen culantro, espinaca, culantro, col, lechuga, alfalfa, además se dedican a la crianza D. animales menores y engorD. D. ganado en menor proporción. Las socias realizan diferentes actividades como servicios D. mototaxi, la agricultura, crianza D. animales y venta D. abarrotes, frutas, gas propano y bebidas. Es el caso D. Yolanda, Olga y Pecina que se dedican a la agricultura, actividad que aprendieron desD. muy pequeñas y ahora lo hacen junto a sus esposos. Ellas cultivan espinaca, culantro, col, lechuga, alfalfa y, además se dedican a la crianza D. animales menores y engorD. D. ganado. La venta D. sus productos lo hacen ellas mismas en el mercado Nery García Zarate al por mayor y menor. Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. préstamos, algunos montos son D. 300 soles, 600 soles, 900 soles, haciendo un total D. 8600 soles D. préstamos para el Banco Comunal Totorilla. El dinero será invertido en la compra D. semillas, abono, arroz, azúcar, fideos, leche, gas propano, llantas para la moto y también para comprar cuy para la crianza. Las socias están aprendiendo sobre cómo educar a los hijos, cómo alimentarlos, a ser puntuales y responsables. Los sueños D. los socios son diferentes como que sus hijos sean profesionales, tener una granja, un terreno y luego una casa y hasta comprar un carro.

loans.use: The members need different loan amounts.Some amounts are 300 soles (Peruvian currency), 600 soles, and 900 soles for a total amount of 8600 soles in loans for the Totorilla Community Bank.  The money will be invested in buying seeds, fertilizers, rice, sugar, noodles, milk, propane gas, tires for a motorcycle and also to buy  "cuy" ( a typical Peruvian animal) to be raised.

loans.name: Chinda

texts.en:
Mrs. Chinda S. (age 42) and her husband, Mr. Rim Toulas have been married since 1989. They have three children—one son and two daughters. Two of her children are studying in the local school and her youngest daughter is still young and stays at home. Chinda and her family live along National Road number five about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. Currently, she is in the business of selling medicine at her home and has started another business selling groceries. Her husband is working in a company in Phnom Penh.

She is borrowing money from MAXIMA for the first time in the amount of $1000. She will use this money to buy grocery items for reselling at her store.

loans.use: To buy grocery items for reselling

loans.name: Kisakye C Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Joy R.. She sells sweet potatoes and coffee and is requesting a loan to increase the stock of coffee and potatoes. Joy is 40 years old and is married. Her husband sells feed for poultry. She has 6 children ranging in age from 2 months to 18 years old, and 5 of them go to school.

Each week, Joy makes approximately 100000 UGX (about $60) profit. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Previously, Joy had a loan from BRAC Uganda for 300000 UGX (about $175) in order to invest in the business, and the loan was paid back on time.

Joy is joined in her small group by Tofa M.. Tofa M. sells coffee and wants increase her business.

loans.use: To expand food business

loans.name: Katwe B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Lamula K.. She is currently in the business of new clothing sales and is requesting a loan to purchase in bulk. Lamula is 32 years old and is married with a husband who sells oil for work. She has 12 children ranging from age 4 to 18 and her children go to school. Each week, Lamula makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children. Lamula has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 100000 in order to buy more clothes and the loan was paid back on time.

Lamula is joined in her small group by Aisha N., Robina N., Kasifa N., and Gertrude K.. Aisha N. has a business in clothing sales and wants to add more stock. Robina N. is currently operating a restaurant business and wants a loan to add furniture. Kasifa N. operates a business selling charcoal and wants to expand to bulk selling. Gertrude K. is currently in the business of running a salon and is requesting a loan to buy a hair dryer.

loans.use: To increase clothing purchases

loans.name: Khat

texts.en:
Khat L., age 53, is a widow with four children. She works to cover the daily expenses by selling food and rice to customers. She makes on average about $6 a day of profit. Two of her children are students and the rest help her mother.

To help the family make more disposable income, she needs to borrow some money to purchase a plot of land to resell when the price goes up, to make a profit. With the remainder, she will invest in her existing business to meet her customer’s demand. (Mrs. Khat L. is pictured with her daughter.)

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land to resell

loans.name: Elizabeth Doris

texts.en:
A. Elizabeth Doris prepares a native food called ‘kenkey’. Maize is used for the preparation of the kenkey. It is highly patronized by the natives of Greater Accra region of the country. She is married and has 3 children. Business is doing very well she wishes to increase production and sales. She is running out of ingredients for her food production.She is in a blue skirt at the extreme left in the picture.

She is asking for an additional capital to buy more food items for her food production.

loans.use: As an additional capital to buy more food items for her food production.

loans.name: Buston

texts.en:
Kamolov Shavkat is 43 years old. He’s married and the father of five children. His wife is a housekeeper. Thus, Shavkat’s business is the main source of income. Shavkat works hard on the farm in order to make his children happy and to give them a good education. His business includes growing and selling agricultural such as tomatoes, onions, potatoes, cucumbers, and carrots.

He has worked in agriculture for ten years, and in that time has gained much experience and a love for the land. With the beginning of the sowing season, Shavkat is planning to sow onion, potato, and carrot. That is why he wants to buy mineral fertilizer and seeds. He needs a loan of 850 $ US Dollars for the term of 12 months. After gathering his yield, he wants to sell his goods to local inhabitants for lower prices than in the market. Shavkat is promising to be timely in paying the loan. Shavkat is counting on your help. He expresses his gratitude to everyone supporting him.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Hortencia Pedro

texts.pt:
Hortencia Pedro S. is a native of the province of Manica in the center of Mozambique. She is the mother of 2 daughters who are both adults and married. Right now Hortencia only supports 2 nephews who are 17 and 13 years old. She studied until the 10th grade and is currently attending the 11 grade in night school.

Hortencia moved from Manica with a transfer in the military service before she was married in 1978. She works in the military hospital in the city of Maputo and has a monthly salary of 3,500MT. She is able to save a little by the end of each month.

This is the second loan she has taken through Hluvuku. The first went to legalize her land, and this one is to initiate construction. She intends to pay back the loan before maturity so she can request another loan to continue with her work.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Hortencia Pedro S. é natural da provincia de Manica no centro de Moçambique, mae de duas filhas ambas já maior de idade e casadas, neste momento Dona Hortencia só sustenta dois sobrinhos com idade entre 17 anos e 13 anos. Hortencia estudou até 10ªclasse e neste momento frequenta 11ªclasse curso nocturno. Hortencia mudou se da Provincia de Manica por transferencia do serviço quando militar antes de se casar em 1978. Hostencia é funcionaria do hospital militar da cidade de Maputo. Tem um salario mensal de 3500,00mt e consegue poupar cada fim do mes. Este é o segundo empréstimo para Hortencia na Hluvuku, o primeiro foi para a legalização do terreno e este pretende iniciar com as construções. Assim hortencia pretende pagar antes do tempo para solicitar outro empréstimo para continuidade com a sua obra.

loans.use: To buy material to build family home

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Bun S., 23, works in the local garment factory together with her husband, Kruy Kry, and they live in Sa Ang. They each make US$ 2.50 per day in the factory and they have one young child at home that they support.

Bun S. has asked for a loan of US$ 600 to open a stand selling vegetables in the market. She sees this additional source of income as giving her family some economic stability and diversifying her sources of income. This will also allow the family to better support their young child and they look forward to the benefits that this loan can provide.

loans.use: Open up a vegetable stand in the market

loans.name: Butasingwa, Zibula Atudde Group

texts.en:
Betty B. is the leader of her group in the Zibula atudde women's group of Kyetume. She is married and her 6 children are all still in school. The main challenge she has is paying their school fees, and that is why she joined her lending group.

Betty is a businesswoman who sells shoes of all kinds from the Kyetume Central market and from home. She has also been a tailor for 6 years, a duty she still performs from her home; she deals mainly in women's and children's clothes. She also keeps cows and pigs, which has helped her in times of need--she would sell a pig and milk to supplement her savings to pay school fees or invest in her businesses. Betty needs a loan to help her buy more shoes to sell and more material for her tailoring business.

loans.use: Betty Butasingwa needs a loan to help her buy more shoes to sell and more material for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Chi

texts.en:
J. is 65 years old and has two wives and five children and must provide for their basic necessities and pay his children's school fees. He is a hard-working man and provides transportation to people on his motorcycle; he has been doing this for a long time and is able to manage his business.

J.'s motorcycle transit business helps the community because the roads are bad and people use the cycles occasionally for transportation from one area to another. 

J. joined GHAPE from the beginning and has developed a lot concerning both his business and management techniques. He has taken loans through GHAPE before and been successful in repaying them.

loans.use: Buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es: La Señora Margarita, tiene el negocio en la zona San Pedro, de la ciudad de La Paz, Bolivia frente al una importante unidad educativa. Donde empezó vendiendo dulces de manera ambulante, su primer prestamo en EMPRENDER fué de Bs. 2000, para la comra de un punto de llamadas y  actualmete tiene tres puntos de llamadas. Es muy responsable y ayuda con los gastos de su hogar y a su vez mantiene a sus nietos, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo, quien le ayuda con los gastos familiares y en mejorar cada vez más su negocio. Aspira a acrecentar su negocio y poder comprar otro kiosko en la zona. Es una persona muy responsable, y buena cliente  de la institución. El crédito será invertido en la compra de targetas pre pago.
texts.en:
Margarita has a business in the San Pedro zone, La Paz, Bolivia in front of an important education building. She had been selling candies on the streets when she got her first loan from EMPRENDER bank of Bs. 2000 that she used to buy a pay phone and now she has three pay phones. She is very responsible, helps with the family household bills, and watches over her grandchildren with the support of her husband, who also helps with the household bills and in improving her business. She aspires to grow her business and buy another kiosk in her neighborhood. She is a very responsible person and a great client of the bank. This loan will be invested in the purchase of prepaid calling cards.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase prepaid calling cards

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: Norma P. is from from Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur, in the Philippines. She is 54 years old and has been working in the field for 30 years. Her husband is also a farmer and they have 8 children who are currently in school. Most of their daily expenditures are taken from their rice farming business and that is why they spend their time taking good care of the field, in order to achieve a bountiful harvest, which means food for their table and for the whole family. She is requesting a loan that she will use to purchase fertilizer, seeds, and gasoline. She believes that these items will enhance the quality of her produce.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seeds, and gasoline for the tractor.

loans.name: Carlos Jose

texts.es: El Señor U. es soltero, de 42 años de edad, tiene 2 hijos, 1 varon fuera del pais y una niña de 4 años, su compañera tambien trabaja para el sector salud, esta solicitando su 9no credito el que utilizara para construir aproximadamente 7 mts de acera; los creditos anteriores tambien los ha utilizado para el mejoramiento de su vivienda, la cual esta en buenas condiciones, el trabaja en el centro de salud "Adan Barillas", con 22 años de servicio, manifiesta que AFODENIC es una de las financieras que tiene sus politicas mas flexibles, por esa razon continua con la institucion, pero en esta ocasion bajó el monto, ya que la situacion esta muy dificil y no quiere quedar mal.
texts.en:
Mr. U. is single, 42 years old, and has two children, one son lives outside the country and a little girl who is 4 years old. HIs partner works for the health department. He is requesting his 9th loan the he will use to construct approximately seven meters of walkway. His previous loans have been used for improving his home, which is now in good condition. He has worked in the "Adan Barillas" health center for 22 years and tells us that AFODENIC is one of the lenders that has the most flexible policies, which is why he continues to work with the institution. On this occasion he has lowered the amount of his loan request because the current situation is very difficult and he does not want to fall behind.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a walkway

loans.name: Morn

texts.en: Morn T. is 39 years old, married and lives in the Siem Reap province with three children, all students. She works in a grocery store making around US $3.50 each day and her husband typically makes US$5 a day selling wood. Inflation has caused prices to soar in Cambodia with recent hikes in food and rice prices have caused economic hardships for many Cambodians. Looking for ways to increase her income and combat rising expense costs, Morn T. is requesting a loan of US $400 to add her grocery’s inventory. She considers this loan an opportunity to increase her income and to expand her business.

loans.use: To add her grocery’s inventory

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort A. is a 44 year old woman. She is married and has given birth to five children. Two of her children are learning a  trade, one sadly passed away and the others are in school. She lives with her husband in her matrimonial home at Koforidua, a suburb of Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Comfort is an achiever; a resourceful woman who loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living. 
 
Comfort has traded in the sale of banana and cassava in Koforidua market for more than five years. She treks to surrounding villages to purchase bulk stock of banana and cassava from the farmers and sells retail to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to buy enough  stock from the farmers to make enough profit to support her family. She wants to use part of the profit to support her children's education.
  
With a loan of $750, Comfort wants to purchase bulk supplies of banana and plantain to enable her to increase her sales. She believes the loan would enable her to save more income to grow her business and support her family. Comfort belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame Bekyere’ which means "God will show".

loans.use: To purchase bulk supplies of banana and cassava.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes was a simple housewife before she entered into selling firewood. Her husband, Apolonio, works as a farmer and he used to help her in the business that she initiated. She is 49 years old. They are blessed with nine children, namely: Lorelyn - 28 years old, graduated with BS Elementary Education, now a public school teacher; Vivian - 25 years old, high school graduate, now works as OFW in Taiwan; Jerimar - 24 years old, elementary school graduate; Judy - 22 years old, undergraduate of computer programming, also works in Taiwan; Dennis - 20 years old, high school graduate; Irene - 14 years old, second year high school; Aries - 11 years old and Jasper - 9 years old, both studying in the elementary grades; and Clarissa the youngest is 4 years old.

Her new business of wholesaling firewood created an alternative source of income for Lourdes' family. She collects wood from the little forest located in their village. To further improve her existing business, Lourdes wants to avail herself of a loan amounting to PHP5,000 that will enable her to pay young people to help her collect wood for her business. She hopes that her current business will pave the way to achieving all her ambitions for her family, especially a better future for her children.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Nike

texts.en: Nike sells clothing materials and fabrics. She needs the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more clothing materials to sell. Nike is 40 years old and married with three children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing materials to sell.

loans.name: Hikmat

texts.ru: Хотя Хикмат 61 год, она на пенсии, но все еще занимается бизнесом. Она продает ткани на местных рынках. Ей помогает ее муж, который тоже на пенсии. Она воспитала 5 детей. Старшие дети иногда по воскресным дням помогают матери торговать. Хикмат закупает ткани оптом на оптовом рынке. А раз в месяц выезжает на оптовый рынок который находится в соседнем Кыргызстане, куда надо ехать в течении нескольких часов на машине. Хикмат имеет хороший оборотный капитал, но для закупки весеннего ассортимента тканей решила подать заявку на КИВА.
texts.en:
Even that Hikmat is 61 years old and is retired she is still running her business. She sells fabrics on the local markets. Her husband helps her and he is also retired. She has raised five children. Sometimes her older children help her with the business on Sundays. Hikmat buys the fabrics in wholesale on the wholesale markets. She goes to the wholesale market once a month which is located in the neighboring Kyrgyztan which takes several hours to get to by car. Hikmat has a good working capital and to buy a spring assortment of fabrics she has decided to apply for a loan at Kiva.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a spring assortment of fabrics

loans.name: Rano

texts.ru: Рано-женщина 44-х лет.Замужем имеет З-х детей.Рано более 6-ти лет занимается продажей продуктов питания в продовольственном рынке Спитаменского района.Рано хотела, бы расширить ассортимент своего товара, потому, что хороший ассортимент привлекает больше клиентов. Для этого она предпочла взять займ для расширения своего ассортимента.Её муж - водитель такси помогает ей с поставкой товара из города Худжанда,где Рано имеет своих поставщиков.
texts.en:
Rano is a 44 year old woman. She is married and has three children. Rano has been selling food at a food market of the Spitamen region for more than six years. Rano wants to increase the assortment of her merchandise because a good variety of products attracts more customers. She decided to take out a loan for this purpose. Her husband is a taxi driver and helps her with the delivery of goods from the town of Khudjand where Rano has suppliers.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the assortment of goods

loans.name: Celeste Victoria

texts.pt:
Celeste Victoria N. é natural de Maputo, tem 38 anos de idade, casada maritalmente e mãe de 3 filhos com idade entre, 19; 17 e 13 anos respectivamente. Apenas sustenta a sua família.

Celeste estudou até 7ªclasse e parou por falta de condições financeiras na Família, a mais de 10 anos que o marido ensinou-a a fazer negocio que consiste na venda de produtos diversos com destaque ao arroz que compra o sacos de 50kg por 850,00mt e vende por 1150,00mt. Deste negocio tem rendimento mensal liquido de 2500,00mt.

Celeste solicita empréstimo pela primeira vez na Hluvuku e no Kiva, com qual pretende aumentar o seu estoque afim de melhor responder a procura nos seus clientes. Futuramente pretende reabilitar a sua casa e conta com o credito.
texts.en:
Celeste Victoria N. is a native of Maputo. She is 38 years old, married, with 3 children of ages 19, 17 and 13. She only supports her family.

Celeste attended school through 7th grade and stopped due to his family's financial circumstances. Over 10 years ago, her husband taught her to do business, selling various products, particularly rice. She buys 50 kg sacks of rice for 850 meticais and sells them for 1150 meticiais. She has a monthly profit from this business of 2500 meticais.

Celeste is requesting a loan for the first time from Hluvuku and Kiva, with which she plans to increase her stock in order to better meet demand from her customers. In the future, she plans to renovate her house with a loan.

Translated from Portuguese by N Aviva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy and sell various products

loans.name: Noralyn

texts.en:
Mrs. Noralyn S. has been a Paglaum member under its PDP-LP program since April 23, 2007. Residing at Nilabo, Rizal, Zamboanga Del Norte, she is married to Rodelio S. and has two children.

She's requesting her loan of PHP 16,000 to use as additional capital in buying fertilizers for their camote (sweet potato) plantation and she's also planning to have their own banana trees as their additional source of income.

Her plan for her family is to finish her children in school until college so that they are able to find decent and stable jobs someday.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for farm production

loans.name: Tate

texts.fr: Tate K. est un jeune homme de 30 anc, marié et père de 3 enfants. il est conducteur de taxi moto à Womé. K. exerce cette activité depuis 4 ans et souhaite avec ce crédit acheter une nouvelle moto. cette aubaine lui permettra de dégager des bénéfices pour la survie de sa famille
texts.en:
Tate K. is a thirty-year-old man who is married and the father of three children. He is a motorcycle taxi driver in Womé, Togo. K. has worked in this sector for four years and would like to have a loan to buy a new motorcyle. This good fortune would help K. support his family.

Translated from French by Andrew Whiteman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr: Kodjo A. est un homme de 47 ans, marié et père de 4 enfants. il est cultivateur à Avetonou, un village situé à environ 100 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale du Togo. Cette activité est la principale source de revenus de Kodjo. Il désire avec ce crédit élargir son espace cultivable et payer des engrais et autres intrants pour sa culture.
texts.en:
Kodjo Agbekpono is a 47-year-old man, married, and the father of four. He is a farmer in Avetonou, a village located about 100 km from Lomé, the capital of Togo. This business is Kodjo's main source of revenues. He would like to use this loan to expand his arable land and to buy fertilizers and other inputs for his farming.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand his fields and to buy fertilizers and other inputs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To change his car's engine

loans.name: Faina

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 

Фаина торгует на рынке больше 10 лет.Раньше она торговала  женским  бельём,но после сотрудничества с нами расширила свой ассортимент товара.Она сама ездит за товаром в Истаравшан раз в неделю и в настоящее время привозит халаты,платья и пижамы.Она благодарна нам за моральную поддержку,что благодаря поддержки КИВА она увеличила свой капитал.Настоящий кредит берет на покупку женской  одежды.
texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. Faina has been a market vendor for over 10 years. At first, she sold women's underwear, but after working with MLF MicroInvest, she expanded the range of goods she sells. Faina travels to Istravshan once a week to purchase inventory. Currently she is selling robes, dresses, and pyjamas. Faina thankful that with the support of Kiva, she has increased her capital. She is now applying for a loan to purchase women's clothing.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase women's clothing wholesale

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.es:
Felicitas es socia del Banco Comunal Ladrilleros D. Compañía.
Felicitas es casada, tiene 58 años y 9 hijos, Felicitas junto a su hijo se dedican a la elaboración D. ladrillos D. manera artesanal. Además Felicitas se dedica a la compra y venta D. tara y cochinilla.
Felicitas necesita un préstamo D. 900 soles dinero que será invertido para labrar ladrillos.
El sueño D. Felicitas es construir su casa en la ciudad D. Ayacucho.

loans.use: Para labrar ladrillos.

loans.name: Mananeh Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the Mananeh Group, who are all businesswomen in the Tonkolili district headquarter town of Magburaka. They are applying for a loan of 500,000 Sierra Leonean leone each from Kiva lenders through SMT. This will be the first loan this group is accessing from SMT/Kiva. 

With the help of this loan, they will be able to improve their businesses, make more sales and increase profits. Consequently, these women will be able to improve their standard of living – they can look after their children better and be able to meet most of their domestic needs.

Kadiatu K. (on the left) is the leader of this group. Kadiatu was born in Magburaka town about 45 years ago. She is married to a businessman and the two of them have three children. Two of their children are in Junior Secondary School I (JSS I), and the eldest is doing some farming for a living. Kadiatu has been a businesswoman for seven years. She sells market food like rice, pepper, “margi,” onions, oil, etc.

loans.use: Invest in theri businesses

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a 46 year old mother of six. She sells household items in Kwanjenga area of Mukuru slums in Nairobi. She also sells herbal medicine at the same place. She is requesting a loan of Kes. 10,000 to add stock of household items. She hopes to educate her children and open multiple branches. She describes herself as hardworking and social.


About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Add stock

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es:
A la vivienda de la señora Sonia J. le está haciendo falta un cuarto de lavado, porque el que tiene actual mente es de madero y esta en muy malas condiciones y teme que le pueda pasar algo. 
Pero en esté momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para pagar el material y a la persona que le realizara la mejora. 
Es por eso que esta solicitando un préstamo para poder construir su cuarto de lavado. Planea pagar el crédito con los ingresos que obtiene de su pensión ya que sus hijos le ayudan con los gastos de la casa.
texts.en:
Sonia J.’s house does not have a washroom. The one it currently has is made of wood, and it is in very bad condition. She is afraid that something could happen to it. At this time she does not have the necessary money to pay for the material and the person to make the improvement. That is why she is asking for a loan to build a washroom. She plans to repay the loan with the income she gets from her pension because her children help her with the household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a washroom

loans.name: Faroles Group

texts.es: El Banco Comunal denominado  BC FAROLES está conformado por trece personas D. edades variadas que oscilan desD. los 20 a los 50 años. El presidente D. la banca es una persona D. carácter fuerte, alegre  y proactiva que en conjunto con su hermana forma parte D. la banca, por otro lado tiene 1 hijo el cual se encuentra en edad escolar, La Sra. Missel tesorera es una persona determinada y proactiva, que cuenta con un niño menor a un año la Sra. Sandra Elizabeth secretaria D. la banca es una persona con carácter proactivo y determinado, las otras personas que conforman la banca tienen personalidades similares. El  presidente el Sr. Alberto se  dedica a la  confección D. ropa (deportivos), la Sra. Miseel se dedica a la venta D. celulares en la feria D. la cuidad. La Sra. Sandra se dedica a la venta D. material D. escritorio (scotch) por mayor lo  cual lo distribuye en las diferentes ferias D. la ciudad, otra D. las socias se dedica a la venta D. comida en su domicilio, otro miembro  se dedica a la reparación D. celulares como D. computadoras. Si bien dentro D. los lugares donD. se desarrollan sus actividades existen otros similares, la afluencia D.  consumidores a los mercados, y el constante crecimiento urbano  hace que las actividades que se  desarrollan en el lugar no se vean afectadas por lo contrario muchas D. las socias están esperanzadas en hacer crecer sus negocios ampliándolos por lo cual solicitan el crédito. Las socias solicitan  el crédito para realizar la adquisición D. mercadería en mayor cantidad, otras para la compra D. nueva maquinas para incrementar su producción, otros para compra D. materia prima en cantidad con lo cual crecer en cuanto a su capital D. trabajo. Este grupo se encuentra en su primer ciclo, pero   la mayoría D. ellas ya se conocen entre sí y cuentan con experiencia D. trabajo en esta modalidad D. crédito.
texts.en:
The communal bank called BC FAROLES consists of 13 people of various ages that range from 20 to 50 years. The president of the bank is a person of strong character, cheerful and proactive who, with his sister, forms part of the bank. He has a son who is school-aged. Senora Missel, treasurer, is a go-getter and a determined person who has a minor child who is a year old. Sandra Elizabeth, secretary of the bank, is a person who is very determined and proactive, and the other members of the bank have similar personalities. The president, Alberto, makes sporting clothes. Senora Missel sells cellular phones in a market in the city. Sandra sells office supplies (scotch tape, etc.) wholesale, which she distributes in the different markets in the city. Other members sell food from their homes and another member repairs cell phones and computers. While there are other similar businesses in the area where they are developing their activities, the affluence of the consumers in the markets and the constant urban growth makes it such that the activities that they are developing are not affected. On the contrary, many of the members are hoping to grow their businesses and for this reason they are requesting this loan. The members are requesting this loan in order to acquire merchandise in greater quantity, others to buy new machines to increase their production, others to buy raw materials in quantity and thus increase their working capital. This group is in its first credit cycle, but the majority of them already know each other and have experience working with this type of credit.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise and raw materials

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
This is Lolita D. S. from Baseco Compound, Port Area, Manila. She lives with her husband Loveros. Lolita understands that life is hard but she says she has to have a strong faith to be able to survive.

Lolita owns and manages a general store which has been around for five years. She makes close to 19,000 PHP a month. Her profits help her to get through life.

In 2006, Lolita joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. The loans provided by the cooperative help her continue her business.

Lolita is now applying for a new loan in the amount of 20,000 PHP as additional capital for the continuous growth of her store. She will re-stock on grocery inventories. She hopes to see her store grow even bigger.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery inventory to sell.

loans.name: Victor Manuel

texts.es: Don Víctor Manuel Rivas, su negocio es la venta de repuestos con más de ocho años en las ventas,  anteriormente trabajaba en ventas y ganaba por comisiones, luego con préstamo en financiera logro poner su venta de repuesto poco pero ha logrado con los años invertir. Tiene su clientela pero muchas veces le da crédito y pasan meses para que le cancelen debido a que no le consiguen la paga total por las ventas baja de su negocio todo esto por la mala economía que esta atravesando el país. Y el queda mal también con sus gastos por pagar. Con esta solicitud de préstamo lograra hacer un muro en la parte de atrás para poder estar en mejores condiciones de seguridad ya que en el barrio que habita hay mucha delincuencia. A si como dar a sus dos hijos que tiene una mejor vivienda, como una mejor educación. Todo esto por el apoyo que la institución ha dado mediante su financiamiento.
texts.en:
Víctor Manuel Rivas has been selling replacement parts for over eight years. He previously worked in sales and earned by commission. Then he used a loan to set up a small business selling replacement parts. Through the years he has been able to invest in it. He has customers, but he frequently gives them credit. Months pass before they are completely paid. Sales are down in his business. This is all due to the bad economy, which has covered the country. He is not doing well with the expenses he has to pay, either. That is why he is asking for a loan to build a wall in the back. He will do this to be able to improve his security conditions. There is a lot of delinquency in his neighborhood. This way he will give his two children a better home and a better education. All of this is because of the support the institution has given him through the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rocks, sand, cement, and iron to build a wall in the back of his house

loans.name: Anna

texts.fr: A. Anna est née le 25 Juillet 1962 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Anna vit depuis 12 ans à Sègbèya, un quartier de Cotonou. Mariée à D'ALMEIDA Bernard, Anna est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Cependant, Anna vit seulement avec deux enfants, en plus de son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Anna n'a fait que l'école primaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Anna vend de la nourriture (riz, pâte de maïs, accompagné de sauce, etc.) à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Anna s'approvisionne. Anna exerce cette activité depuis environs 15 ans. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de l'institution, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Anna désire élever davantage le niveau de son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. C'est la raison pour laquelle Anna sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Anna A. was born on 25 July 1962 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Anna has lived for 12 years in Sègbèya, an area in Cotonou. Married to Bernard D'Almeida, Anna is the mother of five children, all of whom are in school. However, Anna lives with only two children, as well as her husband. The couple provide for the family together. Anna only attended primary school. To meet her needs, Anna sells food (rice, maize paste accompanied with sauce, etc.) at her home. It is at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, that Anna gets her supplies. Anna has run this business for around 15 years. She is a longstanding client of ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), having already obtained two loans through the institution, both of which were repaid properly. Anna wants to further raise the level of her business and better satisfy her clientele. This is the reason why Anna is seeking a third loan through ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of rice and maize, cans of peanut oil, and sauce condiments (tomatoes, peppers, onions, etc.)

loans.name: Moureen

texts.en: N. Moureen is a business woman of 40 years old. She is a mother of 4 kids. She has a retail shop in her area. She started the business 10 years ago. She is using the loan for purchasing retail shop items such as soap, drinks, bags of rice, bags of maize flour, bags of sugar and so forth, to expand her business. She is wishing to obtain a plot of land in her own name and to educate the children.

loans.use: Purchasing retail shop items such as soap, drinks, bags of rice, bags of maize flour, bags of sugar and so forth

loans.name: Juana Del Rosario

texts.es: La señora Juana del Rosario H. C., es casa da y con su esposo el cual  se dedica a la agricultura desde hace 21 años vive en el Barrio San Caralampio, ellos tiene 5 hijos los cuales 3 están casados y los otros dos menores trabajan y estudian,  dentro de los planes diarios de la familia están el tener los recursos para mejorar su nivel de vida y la de sus hijos pero han tenido problemas por la falta de financiamiento de los organismos hacia este sector y que no puedan trasladar la cosecha debido a que no poseen un medio de transporte, ellos se dedican al cultivo de las frutas gracias a que su mamá le heredo unas tierras y las han trabajado desde entonces, es por esto que la familia decidió solicitar este préstamo con el objetivo de compra un camión que les ayude a distribuir la producción, garantizándoles un aumento en los ingresos mensuales que ha corto tiempo se traduzca en una mejora de sus condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Mrs. Juana del Rosario H. C. is married and her husband has been working in agriculture for 21 years. They live in the neighborhood of San Caralampio; they have 5 children of whom 3 are married and the two youngest work and go to school. The family’s daily plans include having the resources to improve their own quality of life and of their children; however, they have had problems due to the lack of loans from organizations in the area and not having any means of transportation to move their crops. She grows fruit thanks to lands inherited from her mother; she has worked the land ever since. For this reason, the family decided to request a loan with the objective of buying a truck that will help them to distribute their production, guaranteeing an increase in their monthly income, which in a short time will translate in an improvement to their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Carlos Morales, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a work truck

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma A., a 53-year-old widow from Quisao, Tanay Rizal, is blessed to have two children, both of whom are of legal age and already college graduates. Emma is a member of the Quisao Center in Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) Rizal East Branch. A widow for almost ten years; she is a very strong-minded woman, working hard to better her life. Despite hardships brought about by poverty, Emma remains strong and dedicated in her pursuit to improve her family’s standard of living. Her aspiration to give her children a brighter future is what motivates her all day.

To make a good living, she has been buying and selling frozen foods for ten years. In 2000, she joined ASHI, a micro-finance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines. During the course of her membership, she has been a good performer with regard to her attendance at center meetings, repayments, and business. She is now applying for her tenth loan, this time in the amount of 20,000 PHP to obtain additional stocks of frozen foods. She is positive that, with access to additional working capital through ASHI and Kiva, her dreams of building a comfortable house will be achieved.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of frozen foods

loans.name: Run

texts.en:
S. Run, age 35, is a widowed silk scarf weaver who lives in the Takeo Province with three young children and one of her sisters. She typically makes about US $6.00 each day, and her sister, S. Ry, makes about US $3.00 each day as a garment factory worker. 

S. Run would like a loan of US $1200 to reinvest in her silk scarf business. She will purchase more silk scarves from the weavers in the village and resell them to the market wholesaler. This business will increase her profits and it would also allow her to save even more for her children’s education in the future. 

S. Run appears in the picture with her sister.

loans.use: To buy scarves to sell

loans.name: Cresencia

texts.en: “By God’s grace, I can still bear harvesting coconuts at my age,” says 70-year-old Cresencia, who makes vinegar out of coconuts and sells them at her store. She also raises pigs to have additional income. Her businesses have helped her family a great deal, and she also wants her grandchildren to benefit from them. Cresencia has been a member of CEVI for quite a while now, and previous loans have helped sustain her enterprises. She is now requesting a loan of Php7,000 to help increase her working capital.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: María Aurelia

texts.es: María Aurelia es una señora que ha demostrado que a pesar de la situación económica de cómo esta en este mundo ha sabido salir adelante con sus tres hijos. Ella desde hace tres años inicio un negocio de la venta de gorditas llamado “La Tonguis”, comenta la señora María Aurelia que empezó con dos kilos de harina y poco a poco fue creciendo el negocio en el que ahora es llamado por los clientes “Gorditas de la Quince” por que se encuentra en una calle de nuestra ciudad con ese nombre. La señora ha ido prosperando tanto que hasta construyo su vivienda y un lugar para usarlo de restaurante en el que quiere terminar de construir un baño para ofrecerles un mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
María Aurelia is a woman who has demonstrated that she has known how to get her three children ahead in spite of the current world economic situation. Three years ago she started her business of selling “gorditas” (small, thick, corn flour tortillas). The business is called “La Tonguis”. María Aurelia says that she started with two kilos of flour. Her business was slowly growing, and now her customers call it “Gorditas de la Quince” because it is located on a street of that name in our city. She has been prospering so much that she even built her house and a place to use as a restaurant. She wants to finish building a bathroom there in order to provide her customers with better service.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finish building a bathroom

loans.name: Isidro

texts.es:
El señor Isidro C. M., es trabajador de la Alcaldía de Chinandega, se desempeña como responsable de bodega  habita en el barrio Roberto González, es casado y tiene cinco hijos de los cuales solo dos tiene a su cargo los demás ya son independientes.

El señor Isidro C. M. Solicito crédito para cubrir unos gastos familiares, es muy responsable con sus pagos.
texts.en:
Isidro C. M. is an employee of the municipality of Chinandega. He is in charge of the warehouse. He lives in the Roberto González neighborhood. He is married and has five children. Only two of them are under his care, the rest are independent. Isidro C. M. asked for the loan to pay for some family expenses. He is very responsible with his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Family expenses

loans.name: Florita's Group

texts.en:
Florita R. is from the village of Lilo-an Bonifacio, Misamis Occ. She is 56 years old, married, and the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. To make a living, Florita sells daily use products such as eggs, salt, sugar, cooking oil, biscuits, shampoo, soap, and toothpaste. Florita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month. 

In 2008 Florita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from GDMPC. Florita is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Florita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Esso-Wazina

texts.fr:
Cet homme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de détail de sacs de charbons de bois et de maïs, il s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays dans la ville de Bassar, il a 5 ans d’expérience dans ce commerce. Son stock de charbons de bois est  épuisé il souhaite se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour se réapprovisionner avec 20 sacs de charbons de bois et 5 sacs de maïs
il  est mariée et mère de 4 enfants, avec ce qu’il gagne de son commerce il  contribue aux charges financières du foyer.
texts.en:
This is a man who has an income-generating business involving retail sales of charcoal and corn. He stocks up in the country's interior in the city of Bassar. He has five years of experience in this business. His stock of charcoal is exhausted. He wishes to stock up again. This is why he is requesting a loan from WAGES for twenty sacks of charcoal and five sacks of corn. He is married and the father of four children. With what he earns from his business, he helps to meet the financial responsibilities of the household.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of charcoal and sacks of corn

loans.name: Béatrice

texts.fr: M. Béatrice est née en 1975 à Avrankou, dans le département de l'Ouémé. Mariée à HODONOU Félix, Béatrice est mère de six enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais un des enfants n'est plus à la charge du couple. Il y a six ans environs que Béatrice vit avec sa famille à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Béatrice aide son mari à assurer les différentes charges familiales. Béatrice n'a pas fréquenté l'école, mais a appris la couture, activité qu'elle exerce de façon secondaire. Béatrice exerce comme activité principale, la vente de bois de chauffage à son domicile, depuis huit ans environs. C'est dans les forêts à Sèmè-Podji que Béatrice s'approvisionne. Béatrice  souhaite renforcer son capital et augmenter le volume de son activité ; raison pour laquelle Béatrice sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un premier crédit.
texts.en:
Béatrice M. was born in 1975 in Avrankou, in the Ouémé region. Married to Félix Hodonou, Béatrice is the mother of six children, all educated. One of the children is no longer under the couple's care. Béatrice and her family have lived for about six years in Ekpè, in the Sèmè-Podji community. She helps her husband to support their family. Béatrice never went to school, but she learned to sew, work she does as a second source of income. As her principal business, Béatrice has sold firewood from her home for about eight years. She gets her supply in the forests of Sèmè-Podji. She wishes to increase her capital funds and the volume of her business. She is why she is asking for her first loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of firewood

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Hardworking K. Julius has been investing in the transport sector for the last eighteen years. His determination and good customer skills have seen him through to this day as he operates on the Ibanda-Mbarara road.

Though with hassles, Julius has managed to maneuver through, earning a profit of 150,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis. With his vision to attain good living conditions, he hopes that this loan will help to contribute towards his need to buy another car for a taxi business on the same route. This will enable him to earn more revenue and be able to fulfill his family obligations.

loans.use: To purchase another taxi for his business

loans.name: Groupe 3

texts.fr:
Le groupe 3 (de l’association Badenya de Zambougou Fouta) est composé de neuf femmes mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles qui ont en moyenne  41 ans, 3 enfants et habitent toutes dans le village de Zambougou Fouta dans la commune rurale de Tesserela dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de mariage. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies culturales, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er  cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Les membres du groupe vont cultiver l’arachide, le mil et le niébé.
Madame Fatoumata   Tata   C. qui est la présidente du groupe compte acheter avec son prêt deux sacs de complexe céréale, 50kg de grains d’arachide et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de récolte dans son champ d’arachide. 
Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles à la foire de Gouassola et recrute des jeunes dans le village. 
Avec une superficie de 4 hectares, elle espère produire 25 sacs d’arachide, 5 sacs de mil, 4 sacs de niébé et du fourrage. Les fanes de niébé récoltées sont conçues en bottes, séchées et stockées. Elles sont revendues de même que la production du niébé et l’arachide pour gérer les petites dépenses du foyer au quotidien tandis que le mil est auto consommé en famille. 
Madame Fatoumata   Tata   C. à l’image des autres femmes du groupe 3 a pour objectif d’assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans le village.
texts.en:
Group 3 (in the association of Badenya Zambougou Fouta) is composed of nine women married in traditional large families; on average they are 41 years old, have three children and they all live in the village of Zambougou Fouta in the rural community of Tesserela in the region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali). They got acquainted through ties of kinship and marriage. In order to increase their cultivated areas, they sought help from Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first cycle of farming loan. The group will grow groundnuts, millet and cowpeas. Ms. Fatoumata Tata C. who is the chairwoman of the group, plans to purchase two bags of cereal fertilizer, 50 kg of groundnut seeds and to recruit manpower for plowing and harvesting her groundnut field. She gets her agricultural inputs at the fair in Gouassola and recruits young people in the village. With an area of 4 hectares, she hopes to produce 25 bags of groundnuts, five bags of millet, 4 bags of cowpeas, and fodder. The cowpea vines are put in bales, dried and stored. They are sold as well as the production of cowpeas and groundnuts in order to pay for the small everyday household expenses while millet is self consumed in the family. Ms. Fatoumata C. Tata, like the other women in Group 3, aims to ensure food self-sufficiency in the village.

Translated from French by viviane reignier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cereal fertilizer and seeds, and paying for manpower

loans.name: Romie Julie

texts.en: Romie Julie L. is from the town of Surallah. He is 39 years old and is married with two school-aged children. Romie Julie owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over ten years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. From his income, he was able to open a sari-sari (variety) store that his wife manages. They sell stuff like shampoo, soft drinks and many other items. He hopes that his store will improve. Romie Julie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Romie Julie is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seed, fertilizer, and other farm inputs. This loan will be his fourth from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Kapamba Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth M., age 35, is single with two children who are 13 and 16 years old.  She has operated a beauty salon and a cafe for three years now.  She works from 7 am to 10 pm daily and she is able to make a monthly profit of about $200.

This will be Elizabeth’s first motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  A motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has end. She hopes for a new motisha loan to buy supplies for her salon and her café.  Her dream is to buy a more hair dryers and steamers and continue widening her café to become international.

Elizabeth will share this loan with her loan group, Kapampa, which has seven members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Elizabeth is in the center wearing a colored blouse.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her salon and cafe.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Sale of cassava flour

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty B. lives in the Ndeeba neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has five children, all of whom are in school. She lives in a home that she owns where she has access to electricity and to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and medication expenses.

Betty has a business selling secondhand clothes. She has been in this business for five years and works six days a week. She sells her products retail at her shop. She also generates additional income from rental rooms.

Betty has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of secondhand clothes. The main business challenges for Betty include transportation and the rainy season.

Betty’s goal and aspiration for her business is to start importing secondhand clothes herself.

loans.use: To buy more bales of secondhand clothes

loans.name: Shermat

texts.en: H. Shermat is a hard-working man who is in agriculture. He has worked at this business for a long time and acquired his abilities in ranching and farming when he was very young. He is a married father with responsibilities for supporting his three children. Shermat is known as being very responsible and hard-working since, every day, very early in the morning, he starts his job taking care of his fields while at the same time raising cattle in his own pen located at his house. IMON International has been the backbone of Shermat’s business because of having granted loans which have allowed him to improve his standard of living through the acquisition of cattle and vegetables for planting. Today, once again, Shermat trusts that his credit will be approved so that he will be able to improve his business with the purchase of cattle and also farm supplies. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer and cattle in order to expand his business

loans.name: Kisiwani Group

texts.en:
Hadija H. is in her late thirties and is married with three children. Hadija has been running her own beauty salon for the past 6 years. The shop is open daily between 8 am and 9 pm and earns Hadija a good monthly profit. 

This will be Hadija's 8th loan with Tujijenge Tanzania. She used her previous loans to increase her stock of beauty products for the salon. She also used the previous loans to start another business selling womens suits. With this loan, Hadija hopes to buy more suits, as well as find a store from which she can sell them. Hadija's dream is to one day be able to go to China and buy good quality suits. 

Hadija will share this loan with her loan group Kisiwani, which totals 18 members. The members of the group will hold each other responsible for repaying the loans. 

In the picture, Hadija can be seen in the back row, wearing black, third from left.

loans.use: Increase stock of beauty products and buy women's suits.

loans.name: Remelyn

texts.en:
Remelyn O. is from the village of Poblacion, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 31 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Remelyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Her main source of income comes primarily from buying and selling canned goods, instant noodles, snacks and junk food in the local community. Remelyn has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. 

Remelyn joined Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc. (HSPFI) in 2010 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remelyn is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and to provide working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Remelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated with her loan to improve and expand her business. 


About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell and to use as working capital

loans.name: Eden San

texts.en:
This is Eden San B., 49, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She has five children, two of whom are already working while three are staying at home managing the household and helping her with the business. By the grace of God, Eden has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their every day expenses.

Eden operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to buy one sachet of shampoo, five PHP worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at the  wholesale price and selling at retail. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 12000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Eden dreams of being able to renovate her house soon through profits from all of her work. She faithfully meets with her fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet weekly. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To expand her product inventory

loans.name: Norabel

texts.en:
Norabel P. is from the village of Kimanait, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 39 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Norabel owns and operates a business making and selling food. Her main source of income comes primarily from making and selling snacks and other delicacies like halo-halo (crushed ice flavored with evaporated milk and a variety of sweet beans and fruit) in the local community. Norabel has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. 

Norabel joined HSPFI in 2007 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase the raw ingredients she needed to make her products. Norabel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase additional raw ingredients and provide working capital. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Norabel from HSPFI.She chose to remain in this loan as her 6th cycle. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her loan to improve and expand her business.


About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc. (HSPFI) is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients for the food business

loans.name: Ana Yolanda

texts.es:
Ana Yolanda, reside en Gualococti, departamento de Morazán, se dedica a la elaboración y venta de pan dulce, tiene 28 años de edad, vive con sus padres, sus hijos Anderson de 7 años y Johana de 2 años, y una hermana, tiene 8 años de manejar el negocio y el pan lo realiza cuatro veces por semana, este oficio lo aprendió de su madre.
Ella está solicitando un préstamo para la compra de materia prima como harina, manteca, jalea, azúcar y latas para moldear el pan, este préstamo le ayudara a disponer de materiales para la elaboración del pan y dar salida a la demanda de los clientes.
Su principal propósito es cancelar bien el préstamo y poder sacar adelante a su familia ya que su sueño es que a través del negocio  construir su casa.
texts.en:
Ana Yolanda lives in Gualococti, in the department of Morazán. She makes and sells pan dulce (a traditional El Salvadoran bread). She is 28 years old, and lives with her parents, her children, Anderson who is 7 years old, and Johana who is 2, and a sister. She has been in the business for eight years and she makes the bread four times per week. She learned this trade from her mother.

She is requesting a loan to buy raw materials such as flour, butter, jelly, sugar, and tins to mold the bread. This loan will help her get materials for the making of bread and to meet the demand of her customers. Her primary goal is to pay off the loan well and to be able to get her family ahead since her dream is to build her house through success in this business.

loans.use: To buy flour, butter, jelly, sugar and tins to mold the bread.

loans.name: Blas

texts.es: Blas, de 47 años, convive con Dionisia, de 49 años. Ambos tienen un hijo: Gerson, de 8 años de edad. En unión familiar, los tres viven en su casa propia, ubicada en la localidad de Ricrican. La siembra de tubérculos como: papa, olluco, oca y mashua; son su principal actividad agrícola, lo que más le gusta a él, es salir todas las mañanas acompañado de una radio, donde al compás de la música cuida, riega y aplica abono a sus cultivos, según afirma “el campo es su vida”. Desde niño creció aprendiendo las técnicas de cultivo; por ello cada cosecha es símbolo de su perseverancia y sus buenos cuidados. En el mercado mayorista de su localidad, vende no solo la cosecha de sus cultivos, también la carne del cordero que cría; pero a diferencia de sus demás pobladores, él también comercializa la lana de este animal, que es muy gruesa y protege del frío. Ahora Blas, quiere comprar un camión, con el cual piensa trasladarse con mayor facilidad. Este es el  séptimo crédito con MFP, y muy alegre comenta, que gracias al apoyo que le brindó su banco comunal, pudo salir adelante. Con el monto que solicita, comprará varios sacos de abono orgánico, los cuales esparcirá en sus sembríos.
texts.en:
47 year-old Blas lives with his common-law wife, 49 year-old Dionisia.  They have one son: 8 year-old Gerson.  The three of them live together as a family in their own home which is located in the town of Ricrican.  Blas grows potatoes, olluco (a native tuber) and mashua (a native tuber).  They are his main crops.  What Blas most likes about his work is going out every morning, together with his radio.  To the rhythm of his music he cares for, irrigates and applies manure to his crops.  He says that the land is his life.

Since he was a young boy, Blas grew up learning farming techniques.  For this reason, every harvest is a symbol of his perseverance and the good care that he takes of his land.  In his town's wholesale market he sells not only the crops which he grows but also the meat from the lambs that he raises.  However, unlike other residents, he also sells the wool from these animals which is very thick and helps protect people from the cold.

Blas would like to buy a truck which would allow him to travel more easily.  This is his seventh loan with MFP.  He comments, very happily, that thanks to the support of his community bank, he has been able to get ahead in life.  He will use his loan to buy several sacks of organic fertilizer which he will spread on his crops.

loans.use: To buy several sacks of organic fertilizer

loans.name: Tek

texts.en:
Tek R. is a married woman who earns a living by planting rice in the Kompong Tom Province.  Her husband assists with her farming business.  He also sells bran for an additional fee to the other farmers in and around his community, earning revenue of approximately $2 per day.  The couple has seven children, five of whom are single and two of whom are married.  Two of their children work and they always share their profits to help with daily expenses.

This rice harvesting season, Tek R. needs capital to purchase many sacks of rice to store.  She will sell the sacks when rice is commanding the highest price.

loans.use: To purchase many sacks of rice to store and sell.

loans.name: Rafael Alberto

texts.es:
Don Rafael R. es trabajador del Centro de Capacitación Profesional Nicaragüense Alemán CECNA, desde hace 4 años, desempeñando el cargo de Instructor de Artes Gráficas.
Es casado con dos personas a cargo su esposa que estudia y su hijo en edad escolar.
Este es el segundo crédito con CEPRODEL los que ha invertido en Gastos Médico, gastos personales y la mejora de su casa.
Agradece a CEPRODEL por brindarle la oportunidad de mejorar su vivienda
texts.en:
Rafael has been a worker at the Centro de Capacitacion Profesional Nicaraguense Aleman (Aleman Center for Nicaraguan Professional Training), CECNA, for some 4 years, serving as an  Instructor in Graphic Arts.

He is married with the responsibility for 2 additional people, his wife, who is studying, and his school-age son.

This is Rafael's 2nd loan with CEPRODEL. So far, he has invested in medical and personal costs, and in home improvements.

Rafael is grateful to CEPRODEL for offering the opportunity to improve his residence.

loans.use: FOR HOME IMPROVEMENT: BUYING CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS TO BUILD A PERIMETER WALL

loans.name: Choem Samnang's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Choem S. is the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the others are attending a local public school. She lives in Samchat village in Takeo province. Choem is a farmer wH. owns a small piece of land upon which she grows rice and is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. La Siek, sells bread.

Choem was selected to be the leader of a group of five women wH. are taking out a group loan. Each member will use her portion of the loan for her own purpose to support her family. Choem has a problem in that her pigs are too undernourished to sell. To improve their condition, Choem will be using her portion of the loan to buy more pig feed.

loans.use: To buy more pig feed

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia is a married woman who lives in EB Magalona, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store and selling food. Her husband Crispin, who is 50 years old, works as a Food Vendor/Businessman to earn his living. They have one child who is 24 years old. Sonia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Sonia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her seventh loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future She will improve her business. Sonia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Farrux

texts.ru: Farrux jenat i imeyet 2 detey. Farrux G. rodilsya v 1959 qodu. On yavlyayetsya IDP personom i pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmetse so svoimi detmi i lubimoy jenoy. Rarrux uje 9 let kak zanimayetsya skotovodstvom. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit korovi dlya razvitiya svoyeqo biznessa. On u sebya doma prodayet yogurt i sir kotoriy delayet yeqo jena.
texts.en: Farrux is married and has two children.  Farrux G. was born in 1959.  Farrux is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person).  He is a refugee from Fuzuli city, and now he and his children and his beloved wife live in the Fuzuli region.  Farrux has been a herdsman for nine years.  Currently, he needs 2000 AZN to buy another cow to develop his business.  From his house, he sells yogurt and cheese made by his wife.

loans.use: buy a cow

loans.name: Louise

texts.en:
Louise is 47 years old and married with one child who is 14 years old. She is well known in the clothes business and this is her fourth successful year in this business.

Louise has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through adding different modern styles of clothing. With these additional styles for sale, she hopes to earn more profit than previously which, in turn, will allow her to continue taking care of her family and keep reinvesting in her business for better progress.

loans.use: To add different modern styles of clothes to her store and a cow to raise at home

loans.name: Chantal's Group

texts.en:
Chantal (with her hand raised in the photo) is 28 years old and lives with her husband, Maurice, and their two children in Cotonou, Benin's largest city. Both of their children are in school.

Chantal belongs to this loan group consisting of 34 women who all live in the same neighborhood. This is their first loan with ALIDE. They have agreed to support each other in business and through loan repayments.
