Carmen día a día trabaja en su pequeño negocio de venta de abarrotes en un espacio que ha acondicionado en su vivienda, ella trabaja en su negocio alrededor de 10 horas al día y puede atender hasta 20 clientes de manera diaria, también en algunas ocasiones realiza trabajos de costura con lo cual tiene un dinero extra para los gastos del hogar; ella cree que está saliendo adelante con su negocio porque es amable con los clientes y sobre todo porque ofrece productos de calidad a precios cómodos.

Carmen está contenta y sobre todo agradecida por el apoyo que le han brindado los prestatarios Kiva ya que gracias a este apoyo ella comprar mercadería para su negocio como arroz y azúcar por sacos, fideos al por mayor, conservas, entre otros; de esta manera podrá abastecer su negocio con más variedad de productos y mejorar sus ingresos, de esta manera ella seguirá luchando por hacer realidad su más grande sueño:”Tener una empresa de confecciones”.
texts.en:
Carmen is a woman with an infectious happiness and she very much wants to get ahead. This is because she has a son who is grown up but for whom she has fought hard to be able to offer him a good quality of life and better opportunities. Day to day, Carmen works in her small business selling groceries in a space she has converted in her home. She works there about 10 hours a day and can have up to 20 daily customers. Sometimes she takes on sewing work which gives her a bit more money towards the household bills. She believes that she is doing well with her business because she is friendly with the customers and also because she offers quality products at good prices.

Carmen is happy and especially thankful for the support that Kiva lenders have offered her, as thanks to this support she can buy merchandise for her business, such as sacks of rice and sugar, noodles in bulk, jams etc. In this way she will be able to stock up her business with a larger variety of products and increase her income. This will allow her to continue fighting to make her biggest dream come true: to have a dress-making business.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Jermelin

texts.en:
Jermelin works hard to support three children. She is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Jermelin requested a PHP 5800 loan through NWTF to buy a SOLAR LAMP.

She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to have backup light in their area.

Jermelin is aware that by using the solar lamp, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: to purchase solar lamp

loans.name: Purificacion

texts.en:
My name is Purificacion S.. I sell clothes for girls. I have had my business for 5 years, and it is located in the market of the city in a very popular area. My business produces income to support my home, and my goal is to increase my inventory to offer a better variety of products. With the profit I could feed my family and provide good schooling to my grandson.

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

Mi nombre es Purificacion S. me dedico a la venta de ropa para niña, tengo mi negocio hace unos 5 años, mi negocio esta ubicado en el mercado de la ciudad en una zona muy transitada por gente, mi negocio me genera ingresos para el mantenimiento de mi hogar, mi meta es incrementar mi inventario para ofrecer mayor variedad de productos y con las ganancias que obtenga poder alimentar mi familia y darle un buen estudio a mi nieto.

loans.use: To buy underwear, pants, shirts, blouses, skirts, brassieres, socks.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice Atieno O. is 41 years old and married with 5 children. She also looks after 13 dependents: 10 are orphans. Three children are from his brother, who together with his wife died of AIDS in 2002. Another seven children are from another brother who had two wives, of which one passed away. The brother is currently on antiretroviral drugs (drugs that boost immunity of people living with HIV/AIDS). She is also living with her grandmother and her nephew (whose mother is Eunice’s sister) and depends on her for clothing and education.  
                                                                           
Eunice started her business in 1995 after having finished a hairdressing course from Pilkington College in Kampala, Uganda. There she got a certificate in hairdressing. After completion of her course, her husband bought her a dryer, blowdryer, rollers, five chairs, a sink and hair-relaxing chemicals so that she could start a salon. Her husband told her that he had loaned her the items so she had to pay him back. Since Eunice had already saved Ksh. 35,000 (USD 500) through the selling of clothes and shoes in 1993 and 1994, she had no problem repaying the items within two years. The business was doing well until  February this year when a fire broke out at her business premises. Seemingly good samaritans, who came in the pretext of helping her, stole her possessions including her dryer, blowdryer, sink, plastic chairs, mirrors and hair chemicals. They ransacked her salon completely. They even took away the door to her salon. She is repairing the damage done to her salon.   
     
Eunice is asking for a loan of USD 300 which she will repay within a period of 8-15 months. Eunice intends to replace the items which were stolen and hopefully continue to support her large family.

loans.use: to purchase a hairdryer, blowdryer, mirror, sink and rollers

loans.name: Reach

texts.en: Mrs. Reach S. T., 45 years old,  lives with her two children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She is a widow who struggles in a very hard daily life to feed their children since her husband passed away many years ago. T. has several years experience  in a tailoring business and typically makes around $2/day, while her two children work at the nearby garment factory and assist in financing their family savings. S. T. is asking for a $700 loan to purchase a sewing machine in order to facilitate her business part of the money is to repair their house to prevent it from leaking during the rainy season. In the future, she would like to have extra sewing machines to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine to run a business

loans.name: Roberta

texts.en:
Roberta R. is 42 years old, married, and mother of 5 children. Her husband is a construction worker and she weaves rugs and sobrecamas. Many people in Carapegua work as artisans in weaving sobrecamas: a typical Paraguayan bedspread made from crafted thread.

She started doing this about 12 years ago. Besides working long hours from Mondays to Saturdays, she also travels to other cities to sell her products. She works from her house at the same time taking care of her children. She sells about 20 of her products per week.

Roberta is grateful for the loans that she has received and being able to expand her business. She is seeking a loan to buy more craft thread to weave more rugs and sobrecamas.

loans.use: Purchase craft thread to weave rugs.

loans.name: Sal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sal M. (29) lives in the Kampong Cham district of Cambodia with her husband. She works as a farmer on the land. Her husband buys bananas from local farmers, which he then sells to markets across town. He earns $5 a day.

She requests a loan to buy more bananas to sell.

loans.use: Purchase bananas

loans.name: Julius

texts.en: Julius is a 29-year-old businesswoman and a resident of the Lumo area, a Dar Es Salaam city suburb. Julius has been in business for the past three years, and currently she is running a shop selling mobile phones and their accessories, a business which is becoming so famous and competitive. She is in need of USD 325 to help her expand stock and thus boost her business.

loans.use: Expand Business

loans.name: Bustonbek

texts.en:
Bustonbek owns a little shop in Istaravshan, Tadjikistan. He is a doctor and works at hospital, but his salary is not enough to meet his family's needs. So he rented the space for a shop, where he sells different kinds of goods, such as perfumes, toys, and household goods. He tries to make his shop attractable for clients and more competitive than other shops in the Shahristan central market, in one of the districts in Khujand, Tajikistan.

He buys his goods from the Istaravshan wholesale market and makes a good profit. For the coming New Year, he wants to purchase holiday goods, and he is requesting a loan of 1000 TJS (about $300).

loans.use: Purchase  New Year holiday items to sell

loans.name: Eliza

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 37 year-old Eliza M.. She is married with four children, aged 12–18, and has one other dependent, who is her niece. In 2000 Eliza established a farming business, and now requires a loan of $275 in order to purchase seeds, fertilizer, and tools. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: Eliza would like to purchase seeds, fertilizer, and tools for farming.

loans.name: Davlatbiby

texts.ru:
Davlatbiby was born in the town of Vahdat. She is 43 years old, is married and has 4 children. She is in the business of selling mainly men's clothes. She purchases her merchandise in the city of Dushanbe and resells it in Vahdat. She asks for this loan to purchase seasonal merchandise - men's shirts. This business allows her to provide for her family and give residents of such a small town an opportunity to purchase needed goods. She is planning to pay off the loan within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

Исломова Давлатбиби уроженка города Вахдат ,43 года,замужем имеет 4 детей.Занимается бизнесом в сфере торговли . Продает мужскую одежду на рынке. Приобретает товар в городе Душанбе и реализует в городе Вахдат. Запрашиваемый кредит нужен для приобретения сезонного товара ,то есть мужские рубашки.Данный вид бизнеса позволяет клиентке обеспечивать свою семью, а также обеспечивать рынок маленького города нужным товаром. Погасить кредит клиентка планирует в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal goods

loans.name: Adela's Group

texts.es:
The Community Bank “Casaorcco” is a new bank that opened 6 month ago. It has 15 female associates who live in the community of Casaorcco in the Carmen Alto district, one hour from the city of Ayacucho. Here, they learned how to be punctual, responsible and care for their children.

The associates have different businesses like raising and selling small animals, grain, livestock fattening, candy, clothing and wood. But, each one has a different story. Adela Calderón, for example, sells clothing at the markets and also buys grain there.

Since each associate’s need is different, the loans differ too. The amounts solicited range from 300 soles to 450 soles to 600 soles, for a total of 8,700 soles (3 soles = 1 US dollar) in loans from the Community Bank. This money will be invested in cattle, bulls, sheep, corn, wheat, barley, peas, wood, clothing and animal feed.

They’ll use their savings to buy school supplies for their children, increase business capital and buy basic needs.

The associates have big hopes for the future: that their children will aspire to something better than their parents; their businesses will grow and prosper; they’ll be able to improve their living conditions; and their children will become professionals.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

El Banco Comunal Casaorcco es un banco joven que se inició hace 6 meses. Actualmente tiene 2 ciclos y 15 socias. Las socias D. este Banco Comunal son D. la comunidad D. Casaorcco que pertenece al distrito D. Carmen Alto, ubicado a 1 hora D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho. Las socias nos cuentan que en el Banco Comunal las socias aprendieron a ser puntuales, responsables y como atender a los hijos.

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como crianza y venta D. animales menores, venta D. cereales, engorD. D. animales, venta D. golosinas, ropa y leña. Cada socia tiene una historia diferente como es el caso D. Adela Calderón que venD. ropa en las ferias y D. las ferias compra cereales.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. préstamos, algunos montos son D. 300 soles, 600 soles, 450 soles, haciendo un total D. 8,700 soles D. préstamos en el Banco Comunal. Los préstamos lo invertirán en la compra D. ganado, toros, ovino, maíz, trigo, cebada, arveja, leña, ropa y alimento para sus animales.

Los ahorros los utilizarán para comprar los útiles escolares D. sus hijos, incrementar el capital D. sus negocios y para alguna necesidad.

Los sueños D. las socias es que sus hijos sean mejores que ellos, negocios crezcan, mejorar sus casas y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: To buy cattle, bulls, sheep, corn, wheat, barley, peas, wood, clothing and animal feed.

loans.name: Hidaya's Hatutaki Matatizo Group

texts.en:
Hidaya is 39 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 15 and 10 years old. Hidaya is a business woman. She started in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Hidaya has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Fatma, Chema and Mtumwa, who have small businesses.

loans.use: To buy more items for her busienss.

loans.name: Luis Francisco

texts.en:
Luis Francisco C.  is 22 years old and is originally from Namaacha, a village bordering Swaziland. Luis is the sixth of eight siblings, married to his wife Rute and has a 2-year-old son. Luis Francisco finished his technical teachers’ education in 2006 and was not able to proceed with his studies due to his  family’s poor financial condition. 

In 2007 Luis Francisco started to work as a primary teacher at a school in Matsequenha, a village in the Namaacha District, and in 2008 he was transferred back to Namaacha village to work as a technician at the District Education Administration. 

Luis Francisco still lives at his parents’ house with his wife and son and dreams of having his own house. He already bought the land and started the foundations. He has decided to apply for his first loan to help start the actual construction. With this $425 loan, Luis Francisco will buy more construction materiasl and will pay the construction worker to start building his 1-bedroom house.

loans.use: Buy Construction Material

loans.name: Nget

texts.en:
Mrs. Nget P., 51, and her husband, Mr. Seng Ry, 68, live in a Phnom Penh suburb. They were married in 1973 and have one son and seven daughters. Five of their children are married, two of whom live in the family home. Her other two daughters are garment factory workers.

Mrs. Nget and her husband have been farming since 1979. They grow rice and other vegetables, such as morning glory, wax melons, pumpkins, and cucumbers on their farm in the village. Mrs. Nget is requesting a loan of US$400 to purchase rice seed, pay fees for plowing, transplant rice seedlings, and dig one well.

loans.use: To purchase rice seed, pay fees for plowing, transplant rice seedlings, and dig one well.

loans.name: La

texts.en:
La E., 46, is married with 6 children. She has many years of experience in the chips business. She sells to relatives and the village community and also to friends 5 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~104 USD).

SPBD loans are La’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will assist her in operating her business. Her husband always assists her with this project.

loans.use: Purchase bananas, plastic papers, salt

loans.name: Zendia C 2017-4 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Martina L.. She sells charcoal and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Martina is 40 years old and is married with a husband who is a teacher. She has two children, ages 13 and 20, who go to school. Each week, Martina makes approximately 100 Sudanese pounds in profits, and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business. 

Martina is joined in her small group by Margret K., Nadia J., Jackline J., and Fasia J.. Margret K. sells clothes and wants to expand her shop. Nadia J. sells charcoal and bread and wants a loan to expand her business. Jackline J. sells groundnuts at the market and wants to expand her busines. Fasia J. sells HP printers and is requesting a loan to open an Internet café.

loans.use: Expand their businesses

loans.name: Nyètaa (Essor) Group

texts.fr:
Les neuf (9) femmes du groupe Nyètaa (composé de 3 veuves et de 6 mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans et 3 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Bozo de la sous préfecture de Markala (région de Ségou République du Mali). Appartenant à une ethnie de pêcheurs (Bozo) et exerçant la même activité professionnelle à savoir la vente de poissons sous diverses formes (frais, fumés ou séchés). Par ailleurs en plus du poisson, elles font le commerce d’habits et de tasses.
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante ce groupe a décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel il est à son troisième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 938 kg de poissons frais et 35 barres de glaces. Elles s’approvisionnent en poissons frais sur place au bord du fleuve Niger à Markala auprès des pêcheurs. Une partie est vendue en état frais et une autre partie est fumée dans un endroit aménagé dans la concession conjugale sur des foyers traditionnels spécialement conçus pour cette activité. Les poissons ainsi fumés sont acheminés sur Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) pour être vendus en gros et au comptant à des revendeurs. Au retour elles achètent des habits et des tasses qui seront vendus dans les marchés de Markala, Niono et Siribala à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 40.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant d’autres activités génératrices de revenus telle la vente de céréales sèches.
texts.en:
The nine (9) women of the Nyètaa Group (made up of 3 widows and 6 married women) have an average age of 45 years and have three children living in large traditional extended families in the Bozo quarter in the Markala sous-prefecture (in the Ségou region of Mali). They belong to an ethnic group known for fishing (Bozo) and are involved in the selling of various forms of fish (fresh, smoked, or dried). In addition, they also sell clothing and cups.

In order to keep up with ever-increasing customer demand, the group has decided to get help from the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, with whom they are on their third solidarity (or group) loan. All of their previous loans have been repaid in full. They are planning to use this loan to purchase 938 kg of fresh fish and 35 cakes of ice. They purchase their fresh fish from the fishermen on-site on the banks of the Niger River in Markala. Some of the fish is sold while it’s fresh and some is smoked in a converted area on the family land in buildings specially designed for this job. The women take the smoked fish to Bamako (the capital of Mali) to be sold to resellers wholesale and for cash. When they return from Bamako they buy clothing and cups that they will sell in the markets of Markala, Niono, and Siribala to a customer base made up of men and women.

They each hope to make an average monthly profit of 40,000 FCFA which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and to take care of their extended family. The rest will be reinvested into their business. They would like to diversify their business by branching out into other income-generating areas such as the sale of dried cereals.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fresh fish and food-grade ice

loans.name: Thi Ly

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Lý 41 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 1997, vòng vốn ban đầu gia đình chị vay 500.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn, thấy rằng việc chăn nuôi hiệu quả các vòng vốn tiếp theo gia đình chị đã vay mức vốn cao dần, mô hình chăn nuôi được mở rộng chị đã đầu tư vốn chăn nuôi vịt đẻ, hiện tại gia đình chị đamg nuôi 500vịt đẻ chứng và hơn 1 nghìn cá giống các loại, thu nhập sau khi trừ chi phí bình quân 300.000đ/ ngày. Chị có 2 con hiện đang đi học. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 10.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi.
Thu nhập bình quân 9.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Mrs N. Thi Ly, 41 years old, joined the TYM Fund since 1997. She borrowed the first loan of 500,000VND (about 31USD) to invest in rearing pigs. Realising the profits from raising livestock, she continued to obtain loans of increasing values and proceeded to breeding ducks. Currently, she has 500 breeding ducks and more than 1000 breeding fish of various types.Her average daily income after deducting living expenses is 300,000VND (about 18USD). She has 2 children who are still going to school. This time, she would like to borrow 10,000,000VND (550USD) to invest in raising livestock. Her average monthly income is 9,000,000VND (about 562USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising livestock

loans.name: Ruth

texts.es: Ruth tiene 22 años, en la actualidad vive con su esposo y su bebe de 3 meses.  Trabaja en la venta de cosméticos desde hace 9 meses, por medio de la invitación de una de sus amigas, la cual le ha favorecido bastante porque ahora puede tener un ingreso adicional al de su esposo, ella ofrece sus productos a sus amistades por medio del catalogo y de esa manera  muestra las novedades en sus productos, durante este tiempo de trabajo ha podido ahorrar, lo que le ha servido para afrontar los gastos en su hogar.  Ruth se esfuerza por su pequeña hija, que es su razón máxima, desea darle lo mejor.  Solicita este préstamo para incrementar la cantidad de cosméticos y también para implementar algunas necesidades en su casa.
texts.en:
Ruth is 22 years old and currently lives with her husband and 3 month old baby. She has worked in cosmetics sales for the past 9 months after she received an invitation from one of her friends. This activity has suited her well because she is able to have an income apart from her husband. She offers products to her friends through a catalog and in this way, shows them the newest products available. During this time, she has been able to save money in order to pay the household bills. Ruth works hard for her little daughter who is her main motivation because Ruth wants her to have the best. She requests this loan to increase her amount of cosmetics and to install some necessities in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the amount of cosmetics for sale

loans.name: Assoupi

texts.fr:
Née en 1953 à Tabligbo, une ville située au nord-est du Togo, Madame S. Assoupi est veuve et mère de deux (2) enfants. Elle exerce le commerce des céréales et des poissons fumés dans son quartier, au nord de Lomé. Avec trois ans d’expérience dans ce commerce, elle a déjà reçu un crédit au près de WAGES et elle a bien remboursé.  
Elle sollicite ce deuxième crédit pour acheter 6 sacs de mais et 2 paniers de poissons fumés afin de reconstituer son stock et de pouvoir bien vendre.
texts.en:
Born in 1953 in Tabligbo, a city located in the northeast of Togo, Ms. Assoupi S. is a widow and the mother of two children. She does commerce in grain and smoked fish in her district north of Lomé. With three years of experience in this business, she has already received a loan from WAGES, and she repaid it. She is requesting this second loan to buy 6 sacks of corn and two baskets of smoked fish to replenish her stock and to be able to do well in her sales.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grains and smoked fish

loans.name: Ret

texts.en:
Mrs. Ret C., 42, is a rice farmer who lives in Phsar Leu Village in the Pursat Province. Her husband has been a construction worker since 1979, and with his many years experience is currently chief of workers. C. has two teenage daughters who are in school. 

Because rice farming is the main source of income for the family, C. works hard. She grows rice twice per year, once in the rainy season and once in the dry season. 

Previously, she has rented a buffalo at high cost from another villager to use to plow her farmland. Now, to reduce the cost of renting buffalo, she wants a loan to buy two buffaloes that she will own.

loans.use: To buy two buffaloes to plow her farmland

loans.name: Perlina

texts.en:
Perlina is looking forward to the success of her business selling onions in their village. They live in a rural area where farming is the main source of living and crops are their main products.  

Her husband works as a farmer and a heavy equipment operator. They are blessed with four children; three of them did not finish high school while the youngest is still studying and already a second year high school student.  

Perlina is requesting a loan amount of PHP 5,000 that she wants to use as additional capital for her onion retailing business. She has been in the business for seven years and she would like it to become stable so she can continue to support the education of her youngest child. Perlina even works double time to overcome life difficulties. She also needs to be patient in order to become successful.

loans.use: To purchase more onions to resell

loans.name: Abdel Majid

texts.en: Abdel Majid is a 51-year-old married man with three children, living in Al Sarafand, southern Lebanon. 21 years ago he started working as a fisherman, and after having several loans from Ameen, he started a small business to distribute fish in the South. Today, Abdel Majid is requesting $1,000 in order to increase his inventory.

loans.use: Increase Inventory

loans.name: Eva Rayda

texts.es:
Eva es socia del Banco Comunal Firmeza.
Eva es soltera, tiene 43 años y 3 hijos, Eva se dedica a la compra y venta de tara, producto que adquiere en las ferias, luego de acopiarlo lo envía a la ciudad de Lima a su hermano que exporta este producto. Además Eva se dedica a la venta de seguros contra accidentes.
Eva necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de tara.
Los sueños de Eva son brindar una buena educación a sus hijos y sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Eva is a member of Firmenza Communal Bank. She is single, 43 years old and has three children. Eva buys and sells tara, which she acquires in markets. After collecting them, she sends them to her brother in Lima, who exports them. Eva also sells accident insurance. She needs a loan of 2000 soles to invest in the purchase of tara. Eva's dream is to provide a good education for her children so they can become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tara

loans.name: Oyubola

texts.en: Oyubola is 40 years old and married with 3 children. She owns a poultry farm where she rears poultry birds. Oyubola requests a $550 loan to purchase poultry feed and more birds.Oyubola is a hardworking woman and she hopes to expand her business. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase poultry feed and more birds

loans.name: Savang

texts.en:
Mrs. Savang S., 41, and her husband, Mr. Him Em, 40, who live along National Road Number One about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, were married in 1990 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. One daughter is assisting her mother in selling vegetables and the other three children are in school.

Savang has been selling vegetables for 21 years, buying them locally for resale at the market in Phnom Penh while her husband, a farmer, grows rice and cucumbers. She is now requesting her first loan of $1,000 to expand her business to better help support the family.

loans.use: To expand her selling vegetables business.

loans.name: Asila

texts.ru: Асила Бобоева-женщина 31 года имеет 2-х детей.3 года назад Асила начала свой бизнес с маленькой суммы.Привозила из Худжанда и продавала продукты питания,постепенно расширив свой товарооборот,она начала ездить за товаром в соседние республики-Узбекистан и Казахстан.Оттуда она привозит конфеты,шоколад и печенье и сдаёт оптом в магазины и продовольственные рынки Спитаменского района.Eё товары пользуются хорошим спросом,так как она привозит товар хорошего качества.Она рада сотрудничеству с нашей организацией.
texts.en:
Asila B. is 31 years old and has two children. Three years ago, Asila started her own business with a small sum. She brought food products from Khujand and sold them. After gradually increasing her products turnover, she began traveling to the neighboring republics of Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan. She brings candy, chocolate and cookies from there and sells these products wholesale to stores and food markets of the Spitamen district. Her products are in good demand because she brings products of good quality. She is happy to be working with our organization.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing products turnover

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: Rosa es una mujer de 47 años, desde que contrajo matrimonio se dedicó en brindar las mejores atenciones a su esposo y sus 8 hijos, quienes en su mayoría ya están casados y ahora sólo vive con los tres últimos. Para satisfacer las necesidades de tan numerosa familia tuvo que dedicarse a diversas actividades, ahora está dedicada a la venta de comida. Su labor consiste en preparar los alimentos durante la mañana, para luego llevarlos a sus consumidores, que en su mayoría son albañiles, por lo que Rosa se dirige a diversas obras de construcción con sus almuerzos. Esta rutina la realiza de lunes a viernes, dejando un espacio por las tardes para atender su hogar, ya que sus hijos aun son pequeños. Sin embargo, últimamente Rosa, ha notado que sus gastos diarios se están incrementando, debido al alza de precio de los víveres, pero como ella tiene un trato con sus clientes de cobrar su servicio a fin de mes, no puede incrementar el precio de sus porciones. Por lo que ahora está muy esmerada en ampliar su casa y ambientarla para instalar un restaurante, ya que tiene los muebles necesarios para iniciar su negocio y dejar de trasladarse de un lugar a otro. Este es su tercer crédito con MFP, y junto a sus compañeras, con las que conforma su banco comunal tratan de trabajar con responsabilidad para no perjudicar su imagen dentro de la organización. Los 1000 soles que solicita son de suma importancia para Rosa, pues comprará víveres al por mayor que disminuyan el costo de inversión en su negocio.
texts.en:
Rosa is 47 years old. Since she got married, she has focused on providing the best care to her husband and their 8 children, most of whom are already married, and now only the last three live with Rosa. To meet the needs of so many people, Rosa had to engage in various activities, and she is now dedicated to selling food. Her job is to prepare food in the morning, and then take it to her customers. Most of Rosa's clients are masons, so Rosa drives to various construction sites to sell lunches. This is her schedule Monday through Friday, which leaves time in the evening to attend to her home, since some of her children are still small. Lately, however, Rosa has noticed that her household expenses are increasing due to the rising prices of food, but since Rosa has a deal with her customers to charge them at the end of the month, Rosa cannot increase the price of her meals. Rosa is now carefully expanding her home to install a restaurant inside, because she already has the necessary furniture, and could then stop moving from one place to another. This is her third loan with MFP, and along with her companions who form her community bank, Rosa works with responsibility in order to not harm her image within the organization. Rosa is requesting 1000 Soles in order to buy groceries at wholesale, and to decrease the cost of investing in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for her meals.

loans.name: Alidou

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de pièces détachées de voitures,  son stock de marchandises a diminué, il sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter  10 disques d’occasion, 10 patins de 18 troues, 15 patins de 12 troues, 10 grands rivés, 10 petits rivés et divers.
Il exerce ce commerce depuis 2006 et s’approvisionne au marché du port autonome de Lomé.
texts.en:
This is a gentleman who earns an income from commerce in automobile spare parts. His stock of merchandise has shrunk. He's requesting his first loan from WAGES to buy ten used discs, ten 18-hole flanges, fifteen 12-hole flanges, ten large rivets, ten small rivets, and various other items. He has been in this business since 2006 and stocks up at the marketplace of the Autonomous Port of Lomé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy used discs, flanges, rivets, etc

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.es:
Candelaria es socia del Banco Comunal Llapanchik que significa Todos Juntos en quechua.
Candelaria es separada, tiene 42 años y 2 hijos, Candelaria tiene un kiosko dentro del estadio de la ciudad de Ayacucho en donde vende golosinas y bebidas, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de sus hijos.
Candelaria necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de golosinas y gaseosas.
Los sueños de Candelaria son mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Candelaria is a member of the “Llapanchik” communal bank, which means “Everyone Together” in Quechua. Candelaria is separated, she is 42 years old, and she has 2 children. She has a kiosk inside the stadium in the city of Ayacucho where she sells sweets and soft drinks, which she does with her children’s help. Candelaria needs a loan of 1200 PEN, which she will invest in the purchase of sweets and soft drinks. Candelaria’s dream is to improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sweets and soft drinks

loans.name: Gulharam

texts.en:
Z. Gulharam is married and has five children. She has been running her own business for five years, selling children's clothes in a store that is located in a densely inhabited part of the city. She is very nice and polite and has many customers. Her business is quite stable and serves as a significant source of income for the family. Gulharam has been a client with IMON for a year. She managed to pay her first loan accurately and precisely. Now she is requesting a loan of 3200 TJS for purchasing children's clothes to sell for the summer season. She deeply appreciates your support and sincerely thanks all of you.

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new children's clothing for the summer season

loans.name: Dany

texts.fr: Dany M. est âgée de 40 ans, mariée et mère de 6 enfants. Elle fait l’élevage de porc et prévoit aussi de faire du petit commerce. Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son activité et d’augmenter les revenus du ménage.
texts.en:
Dany M., age 40, is married and the mother of six. She raises pigs and also foresees working in small scale commerce. This loan will enable her to bolster her business and to increase household revenues.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For raising pigs and for small-scale commerce

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en: Marissa R. is from the village of Landing, Camella, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 29 years old, is single, and has three school-aged children. Marissa owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In August 2009, Marissa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children and supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sonia Del Carmen

texts.es: Sonia Del Carmen C. R. reside en la zona occidente de El Salvador, exactamente en el departamento de Santa Ana. Sonia tiene 37 años de edad vive con su esposo y sus cuatro hijos menores de edad entre ellos; Erika y Daysi las gemelitas de 11 años , Edwin de 9 años y Neftali de 6 años de edad. Sonia apoya a su esposo con los frecuentes gastos de su hogar, es por eso que posee una tienda y ahora para conseguir mayores ingresos también tiene una venta de yuca, pasteles y pupusas pero esto aun no es suficiente para la familia razón por la cual ahora Sonia solicita un préstamo para comprar productos para su tienda y materia prima para sus bocadillos típicos.
texts.en:
Sonia Del Carmen C. R. lives in the western part of El Salvador, in the Santa Ana department. She is 37 years old and lives with her husband and their 4 children. Erika and Daysi are 11-year-old twins, Edwin is 9 years old and Neftali is 6 years old. Sonia helps her husband with the many household expenses. For this reason she has a store and, in order to generate more income, she also sells yuca, pastries and pupusas. Unfortunately this is not enough for the family, which is why Sonia is now requesting a loan to purchase items for the store and basic materials for her dishes.

Translated from Spanish by Kristen Beck, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: stock the store and purchase materials for preparing food

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en: Ngozi, 32 years old and married with four children, sells carpets and rug. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more carpets to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more carpets to sell

loans.name: Doung

texts.en: S. is a widowed woman, 42 years old, who lives in Phnom Penh City. She was married, but divorced her husband since her kids are very young. She now has two teenage children who are local students and under her care. Currently, S. is an internal shipping staff for a garment industry. S. has been building a new house for months ago, but the construction is temporarily postponed because of the lacking money. Therefore, she would like a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL and she will use to finish building her house.

loans.use: To finish building her house

loans.name: Danelia

texts.es: Danelia tiene 42 años, hace más de 7 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que es una mujer muy alegre. Su actividad económica es una librería Danelia tiene 1 hijo que está estudiando actualmente el cursa el 4 año de secundaria. Su esposo aportaba ciertos ingresos a su familia, por lo que eran de ayuda para salir adelante, lamentablemente su esposo tuvo un accidente y el estado de salud que enfrenta es que no puede caminar y pasa todos los días en una silla de ruedas, pero esto no le impide a Danelia seguir adelante con su negocio. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo que será destinado para la compra de artículos como borrador, cuadernos, reglas y tijeras. El sueño de Danelia es montar su propio negocio, y mejorar las condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Danelia is 42 years old and for the past 7 years has been involved in this business which makes her a very cheerful woman. Se runs a bookstore. She has one son who is a student currently in the 10th grade. Her husband used to contribute some income to the family which helped with expenses but, unfortunately, he suffered an accident which has left him unable to walk and confined to a wheel chair. This does not prevent Danelia from continuing with her business. The financing she is requesting will be used to purchase articles such as erasers, notebooks, rulers and scissors. Danelia's dream is to have her own business and improve her living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine B. is from the village of Calaran, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Josephine owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Josephine joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed for her pigs. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed

loans.name: Hen's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Hen T. is the leader of a group of four members who all live in Trapeang Krasang village in Takeo province. She is 38 years old and the mother of two children who are attending the local school.  Mrs. Hen T. is a farmer who owns a piece of land for cultivating rice. Her husband, Mr. N. El, is a construction worker. Although this couple tries to work hard, they still earn less income than they need to maintain the rice field. Thus, Mrs. Hen T. has decided to ask for a loan to buy some piglets for breeding as well as some fertilizer for her rice field.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for breeding and fertilizer for her rice field

loans.name: Rosibell Elias

texts.es:
Rosibell G. es una persona emprendedora, tiene 2 hijos que los manda todos los dias al kinder y a la escuela. Se levanta las 4 de la mañana para atender a sus hijos y luego atiende a sus clientes durante todo el dia pues vive en una zona que a las 5 de la mañana ya hay movimiento de personas.
Rosibell es una persona muy amable, su esposo le ayuda en su negocio cuando sus hijos estan de vuelta en las tardes y tiene que atenderlos y ayudarles a hacer las tareas de la escuela, tambien se pone a estudiar con ellos.
y piensa que con el credito que esta solicitando le va ayudar en su neogicio y tendra buenas ganancias, el credito lo ocupa para comprar pollos, frutas, carnes, mortadela jamon.
texts.en:
Rosibell G. is an enterprising person. She has 2 children that she takes to kindergarten and to school. She wakes up at 4 in the morning to help her children and later to attend to her clients all day; she lives in an area where people are moving around by 5 in the morning. Rosibell is a very kind person. Her husband helps her with her business when the children return in the afternoon and she has to take care of them. She helps them to do their homework and she also studies with them. She thinks that this loan that she is requesting will help her with her business and she will make a good profit. The loan will go towards the purchase of chicken, fruit, meat and cold cuts (bologna & ham)

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Jackson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy chicken, soft drinks, fruit, chorizo(sausage), bologna, ham

loans.name: Los Angeles De Alvarado Group

texts.es:
ANDREA, TIENE 42 AÑOS DE EDAD, ES CASADA Y TIENE DOS HIJOS JÓVENES, QUE SON EL ALICIENTE PARA TRABAJAR Y PROGRESAR CONTANDO CON EL APOYO DE SU ESPOSO. 
ANDREA ES LA PRESIDENTA DEL GRUPO "LOS ANGELES DE ALVARADO",JUNTO CON 6 INTEGRANTES MÁS RESIDENTES DEL DISTRITO DE COMAS.
ELLA SE DEDICA A LA VENTA DE PRENDAS DE VESTIR Y DE PRODUCTOS SEGÚN LA DEMANDA, TRABAJA EN UN PUESTO EN ELMERCADO DE COMAS, SE DEDICA A ESTA ACTIVIDAD HACE 20 AÑOS, QUE INICIÓ CON SU MADRE QUIEN FUÉ QUE LE HEREDÓ EL NEGOCIO.
CON SU TRABAJO HA LOGRADO ARREGLAR SU CASA, COMPRAR SUS ARTEFACTOS Y APOYAR A SU FAMILIA ECONÓMICAMENTE.
EL PRESTAMO SOLICITADO LO INVERTIRÁ EN COMPRA DE ROPA,PARA TRABAJAR LA CAMPAÑA NAVIDEÑA.
texts.en:
Andrea, who is 42 years old, is married and has two young children, who are her inspiration to work and progress with the help of her husband. Andrea is the president of the group "Los Angeles de Alvarado" made up of six more members who are residents of the district of Comas. Andrea sells items of clothing and products that are on demand. She works from a stall in the food market. She has been working in this business for 20 years. Her mother began the business and Andrea inherited it. With her business, Andrea has managed to repair her house, buy devices and help her family economically. Andrea will invest the loan money in buying clothes for the Christmas season.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Fanning, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in buying clothes for the Christmas season.

loans.name: Augustine

texts.en: Augustine is married with 5 children. He is an LAPO client. Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Augustine sells building materials to earn a living. He has been in this business for a long time.  He hopes to expand his business in the future. Augustine hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 150,000 to purchase more building materials to sell. He thanks all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: Eliseo

texts.es:
Eliseo tiene 44 años, y desde que enviudó ha sabido ser padre y madre para sus 3 pequeños hijos a quienes cuida como un tesoro. Ellos viven en su casa propia ubicada en la selva central del Perú. 

Cuando perdió a su esposa se había dedicado al licor sin pensar en sus hijos, hasta escuchar a diario sus llantos, ahí comprendió que sólo lo tenían a él y que por ellos tenía que salir adelante.
Desde entonces, hace 10 años de dedica a producir plátanos, frutos cítricos y palta en sus propios terrenos y en otros arrendados. Esta labora la realiza con la ayuda de su hijo mayor, pues ha ambos le resulta rentable dedicarse a la agricultura, pues gracias a ello está progresando junto a su familia.
Es por eso que para el futuro desea plantar más productos que crecen en la selva central, además de instalar una tienda de comestibles para que sus hijos, puedan generen sus propios ingresos económicos.

Este es el primer préstamo que tiene con MFP y está seguro que pagará el crédito a tiempo para acceder a otros posteriormente, pues quiere seguir el ejemplo de otras personas que progresan con esta metodología crediticia. El dinero que solicita lo piensa invertir en la compra de plantas de plátanos y abono con el cual acelerará la producción.
texts.en:
Eliseo is 44 and a widower. Since he wife died, he has had to be both a father and a mother for his 3 children whom he treasures. They live in their own house located in the cental jungle of Peru. When he lost his wife, he began drinking a lot without thinking about his children. But he soon realized that they only had him to count on, and he had to move forward. Since then, and for ten years now, he has worked growing plantains, citrus fruits and other crops on his own land as well as on some rented land. His oldest son helps him in the business, and the work has been good for them both. Thanks to the business, he and his family are moving forward together. This is why he wants to plant more crops that can grow in the central jungle, as well as set up a small general store to help his children generate their own income.

This is his first loan with MFP and he is confident that he will make the payments on time, so that he will have access to subsequent loans going forward. He wants to follow the example of other people who have used loans to grow their businesses. The money from the loan will be used to purchase plantains, as well as fertilizer which will help accelerate production.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase plantains to plant as well as fertilizer for the crops

loans.name: Bernudis Yaneth

texts.es:
Bernudis Yaneth C. O. es una mujer luchadora de 40 años, tiene 3 hijos en las edades de 21, 18 y 11 años, vive en el barrio la Nueva Jerusalén  del Municipio de  Soledad-Atlántico donde se dedica al negocio de vender mercancía variada directamente y mediante guías especializadas, así como a la elaboración de comidas  los fines de semana y días festivos.  
Se iniciò como negociante porque fue ama de casa sin cónyuge y aunque antes había trabajado como empleada, decidió   hacerlo  por  su  propia cuenta, para poder educar de cerca a sus hijos y compartir mas tiempo con ellos;  Bernudis ha tenido varios negocios, en un principio   vendió  pollos congelados,  negocio al que agregó un restaurante que tuvo que cerrar  porque se incrementaron los costos fijos y la clientela se retiró por el aumento del precio de los almuerzos. Fue  en ese momento, hace 5 años, que decidió iniciar su negocio de alimentos en su casa del Barrio Nuevo Jerusalén, en la línea de hallacas, pasteles y pasa bocas, al èl se dedica los fines de semana y lo combina con la de venta de mercancía en general. Sus utilidades le ayudan al sostenimiento de su familia; ella dice que ser negociante ha cambiado su vida, le ha proporcionado además de ingresos independientes, autonomía y le ha permitido comprar activos fijos como cuando compró su congelador y la estantería para el restaurante. Ella ha recibido 4 créditos con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y es una clienta destacada en el pago puntual de sus cuotas;  en la actualidad aplica al quinto por valor de $2.000.000 para invertirlo en la compra de mercancías sobre pedidos, especialmente sabanas, calzado y cosméticos.
Su principal meta es apoyar el estudio de sus hijos y mas adelante con ellos ya capacitados montar una farmacia familiar, donde no tenga que ofrecer créditos, porque aunque ha aprendido a seleccionar a sus clientes, debe hacer mayor esfuerzo con las cuentas por cobrar. Su mayor desafío es conseguir concretar ese sueño de trabajar en familia en su farmacia, ella reconoce que en ese negocio no se empieza con poca plata por eso debe esforzarse y esperar un largo plazo
texts.en:
Bernudis Yaneth C. O. is a tenacious 40 year old woman. She has three children; 21, 18, and 11 years old. She lives in the Nueva Jerusalén neighborhood in the Soledad-Atlántico municipality. That is where she has her business of selling varied merchandise directly and through specialized guides. She also makes food on the week ends and for holidays. She started as a businesswoman because she was a housewife without a life partner. Even though she had worked previously as an employee, she decided to work on her own. She did this in order to be able to be close to her children while raising them and to share more time with them. Bernudis has had various businesses. In the beginning she sold frozen chicken, and she added a restaurant to this business. She had to close it because the fixed prices increased, and the customers stopped coming due to the increase in the price of the lunches. That was when, five years ago, she decided to start her food business in her house in the Nuevo Jerusalén neighborhood. She sells “hallacas” (cornmeal, meat, and vegetables wrapped in banana leaves), pastries, and appetizers on the week ends. She combines this with her general merchandise sales. Her profits help her support her family. She says that being a businesswoman has changed her life. In addition to giving her independent income, it has given her autonomy and allowed her to buy assets. She bought a freezer and shelving for her restaurant. She has had four loans with the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation. She is an outstanding client with her punctual payments. She is currently applying a fifth time for 2,000,000 COP to buy merchandise on order; especially sheets, footwear, and cosmetics. Her main goal is to support the education of her children. Later, when the children have been prepared, she will start a family pharmacy where she will not have to offer credit. Even though she has learned to select her customers, she must make a greater effort with charged accounts. Her biggest challenge is making this dream of working in a family pharmacy a reality. She realizes that you cannot start this business with little money. Therefore, she needs to work hard and wait a long time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise on order; especially sheets, footwear, and cosmetics.

loans.name: Korn

texts.en: Korn S., age 26, is married and resides with her children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has a child. She is engaged in selling charcoal at home in her village, earning approximately US $4 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially those for her children’s education. She has been doing this business since 2007. Her husband transports dirt to fill out the land for people’s houses in the province, earning an income of US $4 per day. Their standard of living has improved since S. started this business, so she wants to have a loan to expand her business. S. is requesting a loan of US $200 to purchase more charcoal for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for sale

loans.name: Germán

texts.es: El Sr. Germán tiene 53 años casado con la Sra. María Eduvigis Lesme de 52 años, el matrimonio tiene tres hijos todos mayores de edad, el cliente se dedica a la fabricación y ventas de muebles en general, aberturas y puertas. Con una antigüedad  de más de 15 años en el mercado de la zona, cuenta con clientela bien formada, solicita apoyo de la fundación paraguaya y Kiva con un crédito, para la compra de maderas, materia prima fundamental para su producción, y así cumplir con la demanda de sus clientes e incrementar sus ingresos familiares.
texts.en:
Sr. Germán, age 53, is married to Sra. María Eduvigis Lesme, age 52. They have three grown children. He is engaged in making and selling furniture, windows and doors. With more than 15 years of experience in his local market he can count on a loyal clientele.

He is applying for help from Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva with a loan for the purchase of wood, the raw material for his production, in order to fulfill the demand from his customers and increase his family income.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wood for making furniture.

loans.name: Sen

texts.en: Sen M., aged 45, is married and resides with her three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She is engaged in a business selling palm sugar, earning an income of USD 3.5 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Her husband is a skillful blacksmith, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Their standard of living has improved since Sen M. and her husband have had these businesses. She is requesting a loan of USD 750 to purchase more palm sugar and vegetables for resale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva partner. (Sen M. is pictured with her daughter.)

loans.use: To buy palm sugar and vegetables for resale

loans.name: Roberto

texts.es: EL SR. ROBERTO  NACIO EL 30 DE AGOSTO DE 1980 TIENE 30 AÑOS DE EDAD, CASADO CON DOÑA SEBASTIANA CON 1 HIJO QUE SE ENCUENTRA EN EDAD ESCOLAR, HACE 11 AÑOS QUE VIVE EN SANTO CORAZON CERCA DE LA PROVINCIA EL TORNO, TIENE SU PROPIA PARCELA , EL TRABAJA EN LA AGRICULTURA SIEMBRA PAPA, MAIZ, MANI, Y OTROS PRODUCTOS. DON ROBERTO HACE 6 AÑOS QUE VIENE TRABAJANDO CON EMPRENDER ES UN CLIENTE ANTIGUO QUE TIENE MUCHAS GANAS DE SUPERACION Y DESEA SALIR ADELANTE PARA ASI MEJORAR LA CALIDAD DE VIVA DE TODA SU FAMILIA, ESTA MUY AGRADECIDA CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Roberto was born on 30 August 1980; he is 30 years old. He’s married to Sebastiana and they have a school-age son. He has lived in Santo Corazón, near Torno province, for the last 11 years; he has his own farmlands where he grows potato, corn, peanuts and other products. Roberto has collaborated with Emprender for the last 6 years; he is a long-standing client with much desire for self-improvement and for success so that he can improve his entire family’s quality of life. He is very grateful to Emprender and to Kiva for the trust placed in him by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For farm supplies.

loans.name: Nadeeka

texts.en:
Nadeeka is a 27-year-old married woman living with her husband and baby in the town of Telijjawila. Her husband is an employee of Shell Gas Company.  

Nadeeka has managed a business selling small packets of household goods. She buys the goods, then packages and sells them.  Twelve years ago, she started this business.  She is very enthusiastic about her business.

She has requested a 20,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help her business.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To purchase supplies

loans.name: Juan

texts.es: EL SR. JUAN  NACIO EL 20 DE OCTUBRE DE 1965 EN SAMAIPATA TIENE PARCELA EN LA FLORIDA 5 HECTARIAS TAMBIEN TIENE 15 VACAS CADA UNA EN PRECIO DE 2000 BS Y EL TRABAJA AGRICULTURA Y GANADERIA PERO MAS EN LA AGRICULTURA SIEMBRA PAPA, YUCA, POROTO, SU ESPOSA LE AYUDA EN LA SIEMBRA, COSECHA Y COMERCIALIZACION DE SUS PRODUCTOS EL DINERO SOLICITADO ES PARA EL INCREMENTO DE CAPITAL YA QUE QUIERE SEMBRAR OTRO PRODUCTO MAS Y NECESITA SEMILLAS, HERRAMIENTAS, ETC. EL SR. JUAN ES MUY TRABAJADOR Y SIEMPRE PENSANDO EN LE BIENESTAR DE SU FAMILIA, ESTA MUY AGRADECIDO CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Sr. Juan was born on October 20th 1965 in Samaipata. He has a 5-hectare parcel of land in La Florida and also fifteen cows, each one worth 2000 Bs. He works as a farmer most of the time and also raises cattle. Juan grows potatoes, manioc, and green beans. His wife helps him sow the seeds, and harvest and sell the produce. Juan is asking for a loan as he wishes to grow other products. He needs seeds, tools etc. He is a very hardworking man, always thinking of his family’s wellbeing. He is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust placed in him in granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Yuliana Maribel

texts.es:
Yuliana de 29 años, vive en una zona periurbana de Guayaquil, tienen dos hijos de 2 y tres meses de edad, debido a su embarazo la hermana de Yuliana le regalo algunos productos de fiesta para vender, cuando se le agotaron  y por la falta de oportunidades tuvo que invertir sus ahorros para tener mas ingresos, compraron cuadernos, fomix y artículos para fiestas. 

Poco a poco fue incrementando su capital, alquilo un local para tener mas espacio para vender sus artículos de fiesta. Trabaja desde las 08h00 hasta las 19h00pm. Vende muñecas piñatas, cuadernos, etc. Para tener mas variedad en su negocio quiere comprar con el préstamo cuadernos, fomix y artículos para fiesta. 

En el futuro quiere  tener una línea de locales que vendan artículos para fiestas.
texts.en:
Yuliana is 29 years old and lives in suburbs of Guayaquil. They have two children; age two, and age three months. As a result of her pregnancy, her sister gave her some party supplies to sell. When they ran out, she had to invest her savings to increase her income. They bought notebooks and more party supplies. Little by little she began increasing her capital and rented a location to have more space to sell party supplies. She works from 8:00 am to 7:00 pm. She sells painted dolls, notebooks, etc. She wants to use the money from this loan to buy more items in order to be able to offer a greater variety. She would eventually like to open a chain of stores selling party supplies.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Ramon

texts.en:
Ramon is a maintenance worker, but part-time he sells discounted brand-name items. His inventories include perfume, clothing, and watches. He has always liked sales and wants to earn extra income. For three years, Ramon has been selling these brand-name items to family, friends, and his growing clientele. He buys his inventory in bulk so that he can resell them at discounted prices. 

With this loan, Ramon will be able to buy more inventories. He will be able to reach out to more customers and further expand his business. He supports himself, his wife, and their two children.

Ramon has had two previous loans from ACCION USA, which helped him get his business started. With his third loan, he plans to add to his inventory and increase sales. In the future, he hopes to open a storefront and maintain a stable business.


About U.S. Microfinance and ACCION USA:
Have you ever thought about how the cute new café on your corner or the salon you frequent every month got the financial resources to start their business? Chances are, they drummed up support from their friends and family, dipped into their personal savings, used a high-interest credit card, or all of the above. An estimated ten million small businesses in the U.S. face difficulty obtaining loans from traditional banks, even prior to the current “credit crisis”. Microfinance institutions, like ACCION USA, support these “unbanked” small businesses by giving them access to fairly-priced capital and business education.

Small businesses also help stabilize low- to moderate-income neighborhoods and rebuild our economy through income growth and job creation. Self-employment provides workers with a way to increase their incomes, support their families, and strengthen their communities. As unemployment rises in the U.S., more and more people are turning to self-employment and start-up enterprises as a way to take control of their economic futures and provide employment opportunities in their communities. The need for support of small businesses in the U.S. is great, and it is one that ACCION USA has been striving to meet since 1991.

loans.use: To purchase inventory and a laptop

loans.name: Oliver Del Carmen

texts.es:
Oliver del Carmen  de 39 años, vive en la Primavera de Duran (zona periurbana, con una ecología en disolución), ella tiene una tienda de pañales desde que se separo de su esposa el se tuvo que hacer cargo de sus dos hijos.

Por la falta de oportunidades y la idea de mantener a sus hijos con ella, tuvo invertir sus ahorros en pañales para venderlos a sus conocidos, poco a poco con esfuerzo y dedicación tuvo dinero para invertir más, ahora el trabaja con su hija mayor de 18 años en la venta de pañales,  cada paquete de pañal lo vende a $ 9.00. 

Para continuar con su negocio ella quiere comprar con el préstamo una vitrina y pañales para su negocio, en el futuro quiere ampliar su negocio con otros artículos.
texts.en:
Oliver del Carmen is 39 years old and lives in Primavera de Duran (a periurban area with a deteriorating ecosystem). After she separated from her husband, she opened a store where she sells diapers because she had to take care of her two children.

Since opportunities were lacking and she needed to support her children, Oliver del Carmen invested her savings in diapers and sold them to acquaintances. Through her effort and dedication, she gradually earned more money to invest into her business. She now works with her oldest daughter, who is 18, selling diapers. Each packet of diapers sells for $9.00.

In order to continue her business, Oliver del Carmen will use her loan to buy a display cabinet and more diapers. In the future, she wants to expand her business by offering other products.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase diapers & a display cabinet

loans.name: Mrs. Chroeun Pov Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Chroeun P. is a village bank president who has been selected by seventeen people who live in Rung village Takeo province. Each member will use portion of their loan for varied ways to increase their businesses in the current year. Mrs. Chroeun P. is a farmer who owns one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family while her husband, Mr. Ret Nou, is a laborer. Now she has some problem because her field is infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Chroeun P. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and rice seed and rest of the loan she buys two piglets for breeding to start a new business. She is a mother of two children whom all are studying in local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed

loans.name: Chaka

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Chaka Dembélé  est âgée de 26 ans, marié  et père  de 3 enfants.  il vit dans une famille nucléaire au quartier Pelengana Nord de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant  pas fréquenté l’école pour des raisons sociales, il commença très tôt à faire le commerce à côté de son grand frère qui tenait une boutique de ventes d’articles divers. Ayant passé plusieurs années auprès de ce dernier, il commence à évoluer seul en menant plusieurs activités  telles la vente de céréales, de ciments, mais finit par se reconvertir dans le métier de meunier. 
Il mène cette activité depuis 7 ans et jouit d’une grande renommée dans son lieu de travail à Bagadadji. Sa clientèle est due à la qualité du service fourni. 
Dans le dessein de faire face à la demande clientèle, il a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso afin acheter un nouveau moulin (décortiqueur). Il est à son 1er prêt et   s’approvisionnera sur place à Ségou.
Monsieur  Chaka Dembélé fait toujours ses prestations au comptant  à   une clientèle composée majoritairement  de femmes.
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer sa facture d’électricité, son loyer et son personnel. 
Son ambition est de diversifier son activité en menant le commerce de céréales, sinon ouvrir un grand magasin de stockage.
texts.en:
Mr. Chaka Dembélé is 26 years old, married, and the father of three children. He lives with his immediate family in the Pelengana Nord neighborhood in the city of Ségou (in the fourth administrative region of Mali). Not having been able to attend school, he went into business at a very young age with his older brother, who had a store where he sold various products. After spending several years in business with his brother, he began to develop several business activities himself, such as the sale of grain and the sale of cement; he then changed his occupation to grain milling. He has been in business as a miller for 7 years and has a very good reputation in Bagadadji, his place of work. His clientele is due to the quality of service he provides. In order to meet customer demand, he has requested help from Soro Yiriwaso to buy a new mill (huller). This is his first loan, and he will purchase the mill in Ségou. Mr. Chaka Dembélé does all his business in cash, with a client base made up mostly of women. With this loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 150,000 FCFA. This profit will allow him to pay his electrical bill, his rent, and his employees. His ambition is to diversify his business by expanding to cereal sales, or to open a large warehouse.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a grain mill

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong S., 48, is married with two children living at home in the Takeo province. She raises pigs and then sells pigs at the local market, typically making $3 (USD) each day, and her husband is a carpenter. Her husband’s income is $5 each day. Kong S. would like a loan of $1000 to purchase carpenter tools for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase carpenter tools.

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa M. is from the village of Kibatang, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 37 years old. Marissa is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Marissa owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Marissa has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marissa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Marissa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Marissa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora Group

texts.es:
Las integrantes de este comité  se dedican a variadas actividades entre las que se puede destacar  la venta de ropas, comidas, como empanadas, tortillas, croquetas, asaditos de carne, etc.
La mayoría de las integrantes de este comité son madres de familia y  quienes procuran para mantener sus hogares por lo que día a día se sacrifican mucho para salir adelante. 
 Actualmente este comité se encuentra en su 2do. ciclo en donde se puede destacar el sentido de responsabilidad  en las participaciones en las actividades y en las reuniones y los deseos de progresar que tienen  cada una,  además de la responsabilidad en los pagos. 
 Desean que sus hijos no pasen por las mismas limitaciones laborales y educativas por eso se esfuerzan el doble para poder brindar a sus hijos oportunidades de progreso. 
Una de las integrantes es la señora Emilce quien se dedica a la negocio de venta de productos de uso domésticos, aunque no le deja mucha ganancia le ayuda bastante para la alimentación de la familia. 
Así para ella es muy importante este negocio y quiere comprar mercaderías para cargar nuevamente el negocio, mercaderías como fideos, azúcar, arroz, bebidas, y otros.
texts.en:
The members of this committee have a variety of activities among which the following can be highlighted: clothing sales and food (turnovers, tortillas, croquettes, grilled meats, etc.) sales. Most of the members are mothers who sacrifice daily to provide their homes with needed support. The committee is in its second cycle. They have distinguished themselves with their sense of responsibility toward the group activities and meetings and for the wish each has to progress as well as in their responsibility towards repayments. They wish that their children do not go through the same employment and educational limitations they suffered so they try doubly hard to provide their children with opportunities for progress. One of the members is Emilce who sells home use articles. Although it doesn’t produce very high profits it is a help to provide food for her family. This is an important business for her, therefore, and she wants to buy merchandise to restock it. She wants such things as: noodles, sugar, rice, beverages and others.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy noodles, sugar, rice, beverages and others.

loans.name: Mujeres Intelegentes 1 & 2 Group

texts.es:
Marie es una de los miembro del Grupo Mujeres inteligente 2 y 3, un grupo  donde la mayoria de los miembros son ciudadanos haitianos dedicado a la venta de diversos productos, algunos recien emigraron y otros como Marie quien tiene alrededor de 15 años, viviendo en unos de los bateyes de Puerto Plata, una ciudad cuya economía depende del sector inmobiliario, de la fabrica mas grande ron del pais y la industria del Turismo, aunque este sector ha sido opacado por las nuevas zonas turisticas emergentes.  Es una madre soltera con 7 hijos de los cuales los 4 mas pequenos aun viven con ella. Nos dice que su reto o desafío más difícil ha sido sobrevivir en un pais extranjero, ya que suele haber muchas limitantes y racismo por ser una persona de otro pais, y se ilegal y su actividad favorita es asistir a la iglesia, para alabar al Señor y leer la biblia.

Marie está muy emocionada de recibir su segundo préstamo en Esperanza Internacional, después de haber pagado satisfactoriamente su préstamo anterior y haber dado un paso para el crecimiento de su negocio. Ella ha tenido su negocio por alrededor de 10 años, el cual inició con un pequeño prestamo que le hizo un amigo y con eso compro mercancias para vender. Está planificando invertir su nuevo préstamo en la compra de arroz, aceite, azucar y jugos, su negocio es un colmado, una pequeña tienda con ventas de alimentos. Planea utilizar sus ganancias para concluir el proceso para recibir su residencia dominicana. Su sueño es poder regresar a Haiti y visitar su familia y poder ayudarle con sus necesidades.
texts.en:
Marie is a member of the Mujeres Inteligente 2 & 3 group, the majority of whom are Haitian citizens who make a living buying and selling various products.  Some members only emigrated recently while others--Marie, for example--emigrated several years ago.  They live in a neighborhood of Puerto Plata, a city with an economy that depends on real estate, the country's largest rum factory and the tourist trade (which has taken a beating recently as other tourist areas have become more attractive).  Marie is a single mother with 7 children, 4 of whom still live with her.  She tells us that the greatest danger or challenge for her has been to survive in a strange country because of racism and the other barriers that she faces as an illegal immigrant from another country.  Her favorite activity is going to church to praise the Lord and read the Bible.

Marie is excited to get this second loan from Esperanza Internacional.  She met the terms for the first loan and has made great strides in growing her business.  She has operated the business for around 10 years.  She started with a small loan from a friend and bought merchandise to resell.  She plans to use the new loan to buy rice, cooking oil, sugar and fruit juices.  The business is called a "colmado", a small store that stocks everyday items.  Marie plans to use her earnings to complete the process of applying for residency in the Dominican Republic.  She hopes to be able to return to Haiti to visit her family and help provide for them.

loans.use: Buy products to resell.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali H. M. is 38 years old, married and has five children between 18 and 4 years old. He hopes to give them a good education to the university level. His business is located at a busy market area known as Likoni in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many, many tourist attractions including the white beaches on the Indian Ocean. 

Ali has been selling cereals such as maize, beans, sorghum and peas for the last five years to the local people. He says that this business is profitable but the major challenge is that so many people are doing the same kind of business as his in the area that customers are spoiled for choice. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of KES 20,000 to buy more cereals to expand his business while meeting his customers' demands.
