Nuestra socia tiene 40 años de edad, ella es conviviente, su pareja es ganadero y tienen 2 hijos los cuales a la fecha ya son independientes, ella alterna sus actividades del hogar con el comercio minorista, nuestra socia tiene un pequeño emporio en el cual venden todo tipo de carnes y embutidos, ellos tiene este negocio desde el año 2006, la socia aprovecha que su pareja es ganadero y le trae las carnes frescas para su venta. Nuestra socia desea invertir el préstamo en la compra de animales vacunos para continuar con el crecimiento de su  negocio.
texts.en:
Tiburcia is a member of the "LAS TRIUNFADORAS" communal bank which is located in the Andahuaylillas district which is 5 minutes from the city of Cusco. She is 40 years old and lives with her life partner, who raises cattle. They have two children who are now independent. She alternates her household chores with retail sales. She has a small store in which she sells all kinds of meats and cured meats. They have had this business since 2006. She makes use of her husband's being a cattle rancher for he brings her the fresh meats to sell. She would like to use the financing to buy more cattle so that her business will continue to grow.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es: La Sra. Juana es cliente D. Emprender desD. el año 2002, ella trabajo con el grupo solidario Wilacota en 9 secuencias, posteriormente se individualizó siendo esta su 5ta secuencia, como individual, la señora tiene un negocio D. cultivo y venta D. verduras por mayor y por menor, ella es productora, tiene tierras D. cultivo en su pueblo Cohoni por el lado D. Palca, en el departamento D. La Paz; la señora tiene hijos que ya son independientes, ella solo se hace cargo D. una nieta que le dejó su hijo, el esposo es jardinero , en todos estos años que trabajo con Emprender demostró puntualidad en sus pagos.
texts.en:
Sra. Juana has been a client of Emprender since 2002. She previously worked with the Wilacota Solidarity Group for 9 loan cycles. Now she is on her 5th individual loan.

Sra. Juana has a produce business selling vegetables wholesale and retail. She is also a farmer with cultivated land in the village of Cohoni, which is near Palca in the department of La Paz. She has three adult children. Her only dependent is a granddaughter that was left by her son. Juana’s husband works as a gardener. In all the years of working with Emprender, she has been on time with her payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seed to begin planting on her farmland

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is 38 years old and divorced with three children who are  four, six, and ten years old. He runs the D. Communication Network, providing a television reception service to neighboring houses. He's been in this business since 2005 and employs two people. He describes himself as ambitious, simple, and determined to work. He completed a previous loan from Faulu for Kes. 20,000. He says that in Faulu he has learned how to save and is now able to purchase things he never thought of.

He requested this loan for Kes. 40,000 from Faulu to buy more machines and start another business in a different location. He hopes to expand his business and own his own house in the future.

loans.use: To buy more machines

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La señora Juana es socia del  Banco Comunal “Manuelas de hoy II”, vive en el distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, en el departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 56 años de edad y está casada. Se dedica a la compra y venta de cereales. La señora Juana no tiene estudios y tiene 5 hijos.
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 3 años.  Su primer préstamo fue de  S/.300.00 nuevos soles el mismo que le sirvió para la compra de cereales.

Ella solicitará un préstamo de S/.800.00 nuevos soles, el mismo que lo invertirá en la compra  de cereales de la región. Los comprará al por mayor.


Lo que mas le gusta de su organización son las reuniones y la alegría que hay entre las socias.
texts.en:
Juana is a member of Communal Bank “Manuelas of today II.” She lives in the district of Ilave, part of the province El Collao in the Puno region of Peru. She is 56 years old and is married with five children. Juana buys and sells grain. She hasn’t had formal education.

Juana has worked with the Manuela Ramos Movement for three years. Her first loan was 300 Peruvian soles to buy grain. She is asking for a loan of 800 Peruvian soles to invest in the wholesale purchase of regional staples.

What she likes the most about her organization are the meetings and the happiness that exists between members.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Kurten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase potatoes beans and barley

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying accessories

loans.name: La Paciencia 3 Group

texts.en:
Linda, age 24, lives near the city of Santiago in the Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator of her loan group, "La Paciencia" (Patience), and her story is representative of those of the other borrowers in the group. 

Linda lives at home with her husband and four small children. They have a very basic and small home, just one of the many challenges facing those in the Dominican Republic. Potable running water is nonexistent, electricity is scarce, and health care is inadequate at best. Despite these and other challenges, Linda runs a small business selling used clothing to her friends, neighbors, and community. She plans to use this loan, her first with Esperanza International, to purchase packs of clothing which she will sort through and sell for a small profit.

Unlike many clothing shops, Linda will use a cart to transport her items around town. She hopes that this mobility will give her an edge and add to her sales. With the profits from her business, she hopes to buy items for her children, including backpacks, notebooks, new shoes, and school uniforms. Linda is very grateful for her new access to loans, stating that she is now “much more at ease and [feels] valued as a human being”. Thank you for your loan to Linda and La Paciencia Group!

loans.use: Clothing for men, women, and children

loans.name: Nimia

texts.es:
Nimia tiene 27 años, vive con su esposo Raúl de también 27 años. Ambos tienen 2 hijos: Anthony de 7 y Farid de 1 año; esta familia vive en su casa propia ubicada en una lejana zona de la sierra del Perú.

Papa, maíz, arveja y flores de gladiolo, son los productos agrícolas que siembra desde hace 7 años con la ayuda de su esposo. Sus terrenos de cultivo son propios y también arrienda otros para incrementar su producción. Cuando cosecha las arvejas y las flores las debe seleccionar por su calidad y tamaño, pero a la vez es sencillo su proceso, pues después de sembrar sólo abona para evitar que sean invadidos por las plagas y al comercializarlas le generan ingresos económicos considerables.
Por eso que para el futuro, Nimia tiene pensado comprar más terrenos que le permitan dejar de lado las chacras arrendadas y así sembrar en mayor cantidad y obtener más ganancias que le permitan salir adelante.

Este es el segundo préstamo que tiene con MFP y está muy feliz porque le gusta trabajar con los integrantes de su banco comunal, quienes comparten el mismo anhelo de superación. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará dos bolsas de semilla de arveja, pues desea aprovechar esta campaña de siembra. Además tiene pensado hacer alcanzar el dinero para comprar un saco de fertilizante y una botella de insecticida.
texts.en:
Nimia, 27, lives with her husband Raul, who is also 27 years old. They have 2 children together: Anthony, who is 7, and Farid, who is 1. This family lives in their own home located in a remote area in the Peruvian highlands. Potatoes, corn, peas and gladiolus flowers are the agricultural products that she has been cultivating for 7 years, with the help of her husband. They own the land that they cultivate, and they also rent other lands to increase their production. When she harvests the peas and flowers she must select them for their quality and size, but this is a simple process. After the harvest she must fertilize with compost to avoid being invaded by pests and to generate the most income when the products are brought to market. In the future, Nimia is thinking of buying more land so that she could avoid having to rent land. This way she could cultivate in larger quantities to obtain higher earnings to help her get ahead. This is her second loan with MFP, and she is very happy because she likes to work with the other members of her communal bank, who share her desire to succeed. With the money that she now requests she will buy 2 sacks of pea seeds, so that she can take advantage of the upcoming planting season. In addition, she will use the money to buy a sack of fertilizer and a bottle of insecticide.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: top buy seeds, fertilizers and insecticides

loans.name: Yulisa Del Carmen

texts.es: Yulisa Del Carmen tiene 38 años, su actividad económica es la venta de productos lácteos, por lo que es una mujer muy ejemplar ya que lucha por mantener a sus 3 hijos que están a su cargo y además de realizar las tareas del hogar, realizar las compras para su negocio y dedicarle el tiempo necesario a su negocio. Hace más de 8 años que inicio esta actividad económica, anteriormente se dedicaba a la vender cosméticos, por lo que la experiencia la obtiene por el trabajo que poseía, también su esposo colabora con el negocio, pues ambos son personas humildes y trabajadoras. Ella solicita este financiamiento para la compra de materia prima necesaria en su negocio. ella sueña con mejorar la condición de su vivienda.
texts.en:
Yulisa Del Carmen is 38 years old and sells dairy products. She is an exemplarary woman, who is supporting three children and, besides being responsible for her household chores, has also managed to purchase the goods for her business and dedicate the necessary time to her business. She has run this business for over 8 years; previously she sold cosmetics, which gave her the experience she now reliese on for her current sales. Her husband also works on the business – both husband and wife are humble and hardworking people. She is seeking this loan to buy raw materials for her business and her dream is to improve her living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Julia Kastner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie O. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan De Oro City. She is 54 years old. Elsie is married and has eight adult children. To make a living, Elsie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Elsie has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elsie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. Elsie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Elsie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Luis Antonio

texts.es:
El señor Luis Antonio Páez es casado y vive en el barrio San Antonio  de la ciudad de Caacupe.

 El señor Luis es muy trabajador y se dedica a la artesanía de cuero hace 10 años trabajo que heredo de su padre y gracias a su buen trabajo cuenta con muchos pedidos.

  Solicita el crédito para la compra de cueros y accesorios para la fabricación de su producto y así poder satisfacer la demanda del mercado y por ende aumentar el ingreso a su unidad familiar.

 Agradece a la fundación paraguaya por el apoyo obtenido para su actividad  y mediante ello su negocio está creciendo y brindando sus productos con buena calidad.
texts.en:
Luis Antonio Páez is married and lives in the San Antonio neighborhood of the city of Caacupe. Luis is very hard-working and has been working in leather craftsmanship for 10 years. It is a job he inherited from his father, and thanks to his good work, he receives many orders. He is asking for this loan in order to buy leather and accessories for making his products, so he can satisfy market demand and increase his family's income. He is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya for supporting his work, and with this support his business is growing and he is offering good-quality products.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of leather and accessories for making leather shoes and leather-covered thermoses

loans.name: Phoak

texts.en: Phoak T., aged 45, is married and resides with her three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She is engaged in a business producing hand-made products from bamboo, earning an income of USD 1.5 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Her husband works in a factory producing bricks, earning an income of USD 3 per day. Their standard of living has improved since Phoak T. and her husband have had these businesses. She is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase a motor to operate a fishing boat during the rainy season that is coming soon. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motor to operate a fishing boat

loans.name: Julia Marina

texts.es:
Julia F. R., tiene 50 años de edad y vive en el barrio  el milagro  de  la ciudad de Cartagena,  con su  esposo y 4  hijos  en las  edades  de 24, 30  años; En esta comunidad tiene un negocio  llamado variedades Sandy, allí vende todo tipo de mercancías como pantalones  jeans, sabanas, toallas, camisa de colegios y blusas de contado, aunque también tiene unos clientes con los que trabaja a crédito. Justamente para este negocio julia solicita a la fundación financiamiento por valor de $2.300.000, para comprar mercancías como jeans, sabanas, toallas, camisa  de colegios, blusas, a solicitud de los clientes que tiene en diversos barrios de la ciudad. 
Julia desarrolló su capacidad emprendedora desde cuando tenía una tienda con su esposo,  considerado por ella un buen negocio pero muy esclavizante, monótono y no acorde con su estilo de vida, ya que  ella soñaba con uno diferente, menos rutinario e innovador y donde sus hijas participaran como lo hacen ahora en  Variedades Sandy, por eso siente su actividad actual como su mas grande acierto. Cuando decidieron vender la tienda, se quedaron solo con dos vitrinas  y  un capital que fue  invertido en mercancías económicas acorde a su sector objeto;  este negocio empezó a funcionar muy bien y fue así como a través de una amiga que le recomendó a la   Fundación Mario Santo Domingo,  encontró  la oportunidad de obtener un capital con bajos intereses, con él  compró mercancía para ampliar su negocio; su primer crédito fue en grupo y por un monto de $300.000; allí  recibió capacitación con la cual aprendió el manejo del negocio  para lograr lo que hoy es,   “su sueño hecho realidad”   en la actualidad tiene un crédito individual, pero ha recibido 14, con estos financiamientos ha logrado desarrollar su negocio y darle educación a su hijos que están estudiando en la universidad diseño de modas y administración respectivamente; al mismo tiempo sus hijas trabajan con ella y son el trío fantástico, cada una   en su quehacer y entre las tres contribuyen al éxito del mismo. Julia quiere proyectar su negocio a nuevas plazas, y se siente muy feliz con él, pues con sus utilidades  ha logrado construir tres apartamentos, en uno de ellos   vive su familia, y los otros dos se encuentran arrendados lo cual representa un ingreso adicional.  También  el local donde se encuentra su negocio, que al principio se encontraba en  la sala de su casa, es producto del éxito que ha tenido trabajando en su microempresa, y esto es generado por  la unión familiar y el trabajo conjunto dirigido a la misma actividad y con metas únicas familiares.   Julia está  muy agradecida con la Fundación porque creyó en ellos y porque ha ayudado a generar un  impacto positivo,  en la ecuación de sus hijos; es importante resaltar que ellos hoy son socios de variedades Sandy, y se sienten orgullosos de sus padres y de los esfuerzos que realizaron para lograr lo que un día inicio muy pequeño; así mismo la comunidad  reconoce y respalda este negocio  pues saben que variedades Sandy cumple un papel importante en la sociedad y es que ahí todo lo encuentran.
texts.en:
Julia F. R. is 50 years old and lives in the Milagro neighborhood in the city of Cartagena with her husband and 4 children aging from 24 to 30 years old. It is in this community that she has a business called Variedades Sandy where she sells all types of goods such as trousers, jeans, sheets, towels, school shirts and blouses for cash, although she also has some customers that she gives credit to. It is for this business that Julia is asking the financial foundation for $2.300.000, to buy goods such as jeans, sheets, towels, school shirts, blouses, at the request of the customers that she has in various neighborhoods of the city. Julia has been developing her entrepreneurial ability every since she had a shop with her husband, which she considered to be a good business but very time-consuming,monotonous and which did not agree with her lifestyle. She used to dream of something different, less routine and innovative and where her daughters participate as they do now at Variedades Sandy, therefore she feels her current business is a better decision. When they decided to sell the shop they were left with only two display cabinets and capital that was invested in economic goods in line with their goal sector. This business started to progress very well and it was through a friend who recommended the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation where she found the opportunity to get low interest capital, with which she bought goods to expand her business. Her first loan was in a group and for a total of $300.000. There she received training in business management to achieve what is today “her dream become reality”. Currently she has an individual loan, but she has received 14 and with these finances she has managed to develop her business and give her children an education - they are studying at university, fashion design and administration respectively; and at the same time her daughters work with her and they are the fantastic trio, each one in their own work and between the three of them they contribute to each others' sucess. Julia wants to project her business into new areas, and feels very happy with it. With her profits she has managed to build three apartments, she lives in one of them with her family, and the other two she rents which gives her additional income. Also her business premises, which was at first in the living room of her home, is a product of the success that she has had working in her micro enterprise, and this is generated by the family union and the collective work directed towards the same activity and with unique family goals. Julia is very grateful to the Foundation because they believed in them and because they helped to generate a positive impact for her children; it is important to point out that today they are partners of Variedades Sandy, and they feel proud of their parents and of the efforts that they made to achieve something that started out very small; as well the community acknowledges and supports this business as they know that Variedades Sandy fulfils an important role in society and it is there you find everyone.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy goods such as jeans, sheets, towels, school shirts and blouses

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna L. is from the village of Talon, Gingoog City. She is 50 years old, married, and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Lorna operates a buying and selling business, buying agricultural crops like bananas, cassava and copra. She then transports these crops and sells them in the city. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $50 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lorna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase crops and also as additional working capital. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more agricultural crops to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more agricultural crops to sell

loans.name: San Miguel Group

texts.es:
Este Comité se formo gracias a las gestiones que hicieron las señoras  Victoriana Zarza y Ana Epifania A..
Hoy día el comité se encuentra trabajando con mucha esperanza y entusiasmo, ya que el trabajo que cada una realiza le genera ingreso para su familia.
Se puede hablar de la  Ana Epifania A. Vda de Villar, quien  tiene 51 años.
Ella vive con su único Hijo, soltero ,31 años quién es chofer y le ayuda con los gastos de la casa. Es una señora muy trabajadora, ella se dedica a la confección de ao po’i y bordados en distintos tipos de telas.
Todos sus trabajos son muy llamativos, originales y creativos por lo son vendidas fácilmente en los negocios de la ciudad.
texts.en:
This committee was formed thanks to efforts made by Victoriana Zarza and Ana Epifania A.. The committee is working with much hope and enthusiasm because the work which each one does generates income for their family. We feature Ana Epifania A. Vda de Villar, 51. She lives with her only single son, 31, who is a driver and helps out with household expenses. She is a very hard-working woman. She makes ao poí (Peruvian craft) and embroiders on different kinds of fabric. All of her items are very eye-catching, original and creative so they sell easily in the city’s stores.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ao po'i (Peruvian craft) fabrics.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of condiments

loans.name: Kutimuy Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Kutimuy que significa Regresa en quechua, inicia su ciclo 42 con 13 socias.
Zoila es socia D. muchos años, inicio con un ahorro D. 1 dólar en otro banco comunal, ahora integra el Banco Comunal Kutimuy y tiene nuevas amigas, durante este tiempo aprendió a ser puntual, responsable, y sobre todo a ahorrar con su dinero pudo terminar D. construir su casa.
Zoila tiene 60 años y vive con sus nietas que están a su responsabilidad, tiene una tienda en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes en general, verduras, carnes, actividad que realiza con la ayuda D. su nieta. Además Zoila viaja a las ferias en donD. venD. verduras, panes y D. allá compra cereales, carne que venD. en su tienda.
Su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. arroz y azúcar.
Zoila sueña con tener mas ahorros para su vejez y superarse mas.
texts.en:
The Kutimuy Communal Bank (Kutimuy means “to return” in quechua) begins its 42nd cycle with 13 members. Zoila is a long-time member: she started with another communal bank, saving 1 dollar, and now she is part of the Kutimuy Communal Bank and has maD. new friends. During this time she has learned to be punctual, responsible and, most of all, to save her money, and this way she could finish building her house. Zoila is 60 years old and she lives with her nieces, who are under her responsibility. She has set up a shop in her house where she sells groceries, vegetables and meat, and her niece helps her in this business. Moreover, Zoila travels to various fairs, where she sells vegetables, bread and buys cereals and meat she then resells in her shop. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy rice and sugar. Zoila dreams of increasing her savings for her old age and of excelling in her job even more.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice and sugar

loans.name: Consolacion

texts.en:
Consolacion V. is a 41-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy. Kabangbang, Bantayan, Cebu City. She earns her living by selling bags and footwear.

Consolacion’s 45-year-old husband, Jumar, helps her in running the business. They have four children who are between 16 and 22 years old. The children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Consolacion joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 hoping that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of their family's life. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income through her business. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 36,000 from her business activities.

Consolacion is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 was used to fund operations of her business selling ready-to-wear clothes and footwear. It had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 22nd cycle loan, the amount of PHP 29,500, which she intends to use on her business selling bags and footwear. Consolacion is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Khawla

texts.en:
Khawla B. runs a small family business with her husband. They have owned a small women's clothing shop for two years. Khawla is thinking of improving the shop by adding stands and equipment to exhibit the clothes in order to have a better clothing display for their customers.

Khawla took a $1,500 loan from FATEN to improve her shop. She would like to take a another one after she repays the current one so she can have a specialized women's shop in the future.

In the photograph, Khawla's stands next to women's clothes that she sells in her shop.

loans.use: Purchase shop accessories

loans.name: Larisa

texts.en:
Larisa is married with an 11-year-old daughter, Alina. Larisa is a clothing sales entrepreneur from Novomoskovsk in the Dnepropetrovsk region. She sells men's outerwear, such as jeans, shirts and t-shirts in the central market of her home town. Her hard work and natural openness have been instrumental in her business expansion. Larisa has been in the market for six years. Currently, she has 30,000 UAH in inventory. 

Larisa is hoping to use the loan of 16,400 UAH to purchase additional merchandise and diversify the assortment of inventory she offers for sale. Larisa's business is a considerable contribution to the family's budget. She and her husband work hard to make some savings to pay for their daughter's studies in college.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise and expand her assortment

loans.name: Tavai

texts.en:
Tavai F. is 24 and married with one child.  She owns a business venture selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community.  Tavai has 3 years of experience in this business.  Tavai needs a loan of WST 2000 to invest in expanding the business.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US$ 167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Tavai joined SPBD.    This is her 4th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Tavai's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 

In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  

http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah K. lives in Bwaise neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has 7 children, four of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren). 

Sarah has a business of selling charcoal. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Sarah sells her products at the market by retail. Sarah has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. She owns rental rooms, as an additional source of income. The main business challenge(s) for Sarah include rainy season. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start going directly to villages for charcoal. Sarah lives in a home that she owns; she doesn't have access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, and medication expense(s).

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Jose Saul

texts.es:
el sr. Jose Saul M. tiene 54 años de edad, vive en union libre y tiene 4 hijos que dependen de el.
Su trabajo es la compra/venta de agua en bote, botellones, bolsas, refrescos y abarroteria en su casa, ademas realiza trabajos para la alcaldia de San Lorenzo como motorista de una volqueta.
el negocio cuando el no esta lo atiende su compañera de hogar.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de agua.
su mayor deseo es que su familia viva comodamente.
texts.en:
Jose Saul M. is 54 years old and lives with his life partner and four children who depend on him for support. He buys and sells water in cans, large bottles, and bags; buys and sells soft drinks, and groceries out of his home; and also does work for the San Lorenzo city hall driving a dump truck. When he is not at home, his live in partner tends to the business. He will use the money from this loan to buy water. His greatest desire is for his family to live comfortably.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Azalia Graciela

texts.es:
la sra. Azalia Graciela Z. H. tiene una pulperia que esta ubicada en su casa de habitacion la cual opera bajo el nombre de Pulpería y Variedades  "AZALIA".
Azalia es madre de 4 hijos, 3 estudian en la secundaria y uno en primaria de los centros educativos publicos de la ciudad. 
La  Sra Azalia es una mujer muy emprendedora con deseos de superacion ya que es madre soltera y como madre quiere dar todo lo mejor para sus hijos, que ellos se preparen y sean personas de bien en su vida. 
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de mercaderia y asi tener mas surtida su pulperia.
su meta es hacer lo mas grande posible su negocio.
las ganancias las necesita para salir adelante con sus hijos.
texts.en:
Ms. Azalia Graciela Z. H. owns a general store called Pulpería y Variedades "AZALIA," which she runs from home. She has 4 children, 3 of whom are in secondary school while one attends a public elementary school in the city.

Ms. Azalia is an enterprising woman who has the desire for self-improvement. She is a single mother and as such, wants to give her children the best so that they can be better prepared to become decent people in life.

She will use this loan in order to purchase goods, thus better stocking her general store. Her goal is to expand her business as much as possible. She needs these profits so that she and her children can get ahead in life.

loans.use: Purchase lard, sugar, eggs, cooking oil, margarine, dairy products, soups, churros, soft drinks, juice, sardines, candles, matches, beans, cornmeal, flour, cookies, candies, bathroom tissue, pills, and bottled water

loans.name: C2361 Abishyizehamwe Group

texts.en:
Jaqueline is 29 years old and married with two children: the first one is 5 years old and the last one is 1 and a half years old. Jaqueline also takes care of two dependent relatives. In her family, there is a driver, who helps Jaqueline care for her family. Jaqueline owns a small business selling various vegetables and fruits. In addition, Jaqueline is the leader of a group of five people with various businesses.

Jaqueline and her group are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand their businesses by purchasing more products needed by their customers. With this loan, the group members will be able to sort out their family problems and their businesses as well.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Daylinda

texts.en:
Daylinda M. is from the village of Talisayan, Misamis Oriental. She is 45 years old. Daylinda is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Daylinda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, junk foods, canned goods, & instant noodles in the local community. Daylinda has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Daylinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Daylinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Daylinda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Daylinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie L. is from the village of Benhaan in Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old. Tessie is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Tessie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, junk foods, instant noodles & biscuits in the local community. Tessie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Tessie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be Tessie's third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Mrs. Teresita L. is from the Barangay of P12 Northern Catadman, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old and married to Jesus L.. The couple is blessed with three children who are all now adults. To make a living, Teresita and her husband are presently engaged in a cakes and pastries-making and a ready-to-wear clothing business. They’ve been engaged in their businesses for five years already. They are currently earning no less than 6000 PHP per month. 

In 2008, Teresita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. As an active member of PMPC under the Regular Loan Program, Teresita has successfully repaid a loan amount of 35,000 PHP.  She is now requesting a loan of 30,000 PHP as her seventh loan which will be used for the additional capital for their existing cakes and pastries-making and ready-to-wear clothing businesses. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, making loan repayments and investing in possible business expansions.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To obtain additional capital for their existing cakes and pastriesmaking and RTW dealing business

loans.name: Liberty

texts.en:
Liberty M. is a married woman who lives in 112 Brgy. Dancalan, Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, a buying and selling ready-to-wear clothes business, and a farming (sugarcane) business. Her husband, Agapito, who is 56 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's businesses. They have 12 children aged between 5 and 30.
Liberty joined Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Liberty has been gradually lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 9,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 9,000 PHP, raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing 12,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy stocks for the general store and fertilizer for her sugarcane. Liberty wants to continue to save up for the future education of her children and to improve her business. Liberty M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: buying cartons of fish for resale

loans.name: Leilyn

texts.en:
Leilyn, 29 years old, is from the town of Santa Josefa. She is married and has a 3-year-old child. Leilyn is engaged in farming. She plants and harvests rice crops. She currently earns approximately $47 a month from farming. Leilyn also raises hogs for fattening and sale. She works hard to help provide her family's needs.

Leilyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. 

Leilyn is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to buy seeds, fertilizers and pig feeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers and pig feed

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es: Victoria, es una mujer decidida y hábil, de 47 años. Vive en compañía de su esposo Alberto y sus 3 hijos, con los que sale adelante en la localidad de Playa Hermosa – San Ramón (selva central peruana). El trabajo al que se dedica desde hace ya algunos años, es la confección de cortinas y manteles, los que comercializa en las ferias que se realizan en la localidad. Todos los miércoles, viernes y sábados. Pero conocedores de su arte, Victoria tiene clientes que le compran sus lindos manteles de mesa. Lo que más le gusta a ella es poder plasmar sus ideas en sus confecciones. Por ello tiene pensado para el futuro comprar máquinas de última generación, y así poder vender sus confecciones al por mayor. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Los Claveles”, y está es la segunda vez que trabaja con MFP, demostrando compromiso y éxito con los integrantes de su asociación. Victoria cada mes compra la mercadería necesaria para su negocio, por ello con el crédito que solicita, comprará varias telas, de diferentes colores y texturas.
texts.en: Victoria is a 47 year-old woman who is determined and highly skilled.  She lives with her husband, Alberto, and their 3 children in the locality of Playa Hermosa-San Ramon (in the central Peruvian rainforest.)  For some years now she has been making curtains and tablecloths that she sells in the markets that take place in her region every Wednesday, Friday and Saturday.  Victoria has customers who know of her art and who buy her beautiful tablecloths.  What she likes most is to be able to give shape to their ideas in her products.  In the future she is planning to purchase some state-of-the-art sewing machines so that she can sell her products at wholesale.  She belongs to the communal bank "Los Claveles," and this is the second time that she has worked with MFP, demonstrating commitment and success with the other members of her group.  Every month Victoria buys the merchandise she needs for her business, and to do this she requests a loan to buy a variety of fabrics of different colors and textures.

loans.use: to buy fabric of different designs and colors

loans.name: The Francisca Lo Group

texts.en:
Francisca L. is from the village of Calamagui 1st. She is 64 years old and the leader of “The Francisca L. Group,” an eight-member borrowing group that is receiving an ASKI loan. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. 

Francisca is widowed and has four adult children. To make a living, Francisca owns and operates a business making and selling food. Her main source of income comes from preparing and selling food for daily meals. Francisca has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. 

Francisca joined ASKI in 2004 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Francisca has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Francisca is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the thirteenth loan taken out by Francisca from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated with this loan to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products

loans.name: Mirna Maria

texts.es:
La Sra. Mirna María O. M., es madre soltera de tres  hijos de los cuales todos están a su cargo, actualmente se dedica a la venta de plástico  en el mercado la estación de la ciudad de León, cabe mencionar que lleva 12 años dedicados a esta labor, lo que ha venido ayudarle a mejorar las condiciones de vida de ella y su familia,  realiza su compra de platicos dos veces por semana en la ciudad de Managua y las piñata  las elabora personalmente ella. 
Cabe mencionar que con los créditos que Ceprodel  le ha brindado a  logrado a incrementar su inventario con productos de mejor calidad y así  tiene mayores venta lo que le ayudado tener mayor ganancia.
texts.en:
Sra. Mirna María O. M. is a single mother of three children, all of whom are in her care. She currently sells plastics at the station market in the city of León. It should be mentioned that she has devoted twelve years to this business, which has helped improve the living conditions for herself and her family. Mirna buys plastics twice a week in the city of Managua. She personally makes piñatas, which she also sells.

The loans from CEPRODEL have allowed her to increase her inventory by acquiring products of better quality. As a result, she has generated better sales which means she has more income.

loans.use: Purchase plastic goods & supplies for making piñatas

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 29 years old and is married with one child who is one year old. Emmanuel sells shoes in his market and his business is well-organized. Emmanuel employs one person to help him and he starts from 7am until 9pm every day and he has three years' experience in his business.

Emmanuel has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to purchase more shoes for sale. With his profits, Emmanuel will reinvest in his business, satisfy his customers and he will build his own house.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
48-year-old Merlyn is a married woman with 3 children. Her children's ages are 24, 21 and 14.

Merlyn raises pigs to earn a living. She fattens the pigs and sells them to the market. Merlyn also grows cassava and sells cassava root crops. Merlyn works hard to support her family.

Merlyn's loan will be used to purchase feed, vitamins and other supplies.

loans.use: to purchase feed, vitamins and other supplies

loans.name: Amparo

texts.en:
Amparo D. is from the village of Barangay 18, Gingoog City. She is 56 years old. Amparo is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Amparo owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, junk foods, beverages & biscuits in the local community. Amparo has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Amparo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Amparo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Amparo is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods & junk foods. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Amparo from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods & junk foods.

loans.name: Damba

texts.en:
Damba is 22 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in a house in Hovd province, Mongolia. His wife is a cook at a private bakery company. He manages a taxi service business in his town. He started his business in 2009. 

His mother owns a small grocery trading business at a rented stall in a local market. Her business was quite successful and encouraged him to become part of that business. So Damba is planning to conduct his mother's business together with her. He is requesting a 1,300,000 MNT loan to purchase fruits and vegetables for his new business.

loans.use: to purchase fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Simon Maina

texts.en:
Simon has operated his retail shop in Ndunyu Njeru town for the past seven years.  He is 32 years, married to Teresia Wanjiku and they have two children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our field officers and this will be his second loan.  He paid his previous loan well and in good time.  He plans to use this loan to buy more goods for sale in his retail shop.

In the future, Simon hopes to grow his retail shop to wholesale.

loans.use: to buy more retail products, such as rice, sugar and bar soap

loans.name: Eliud

texts.en:
Eliud is 51 years old.  He is married to Monica, who also contributes to the family income. He has two children aged 23 and 20.  Eluid is a farmer and has been growing coffee for a period of about eight years, earning an income of KES 7,000 a month.

This is Eliud's second loan from KADET after successfully repaying his previous one. He has requested this loan to pay school fees for his children. 

His hope is to enhance his children’s future dreams and improve their living standard.

loans.use: pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Loida

texts.en:
Loida is 33 years old.  She is married and has 3 children.  With all 3 children in school, Loida works very hard to provide for them.  She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has been in this business for 10 years.  She sells a variety of items such as noodles, curls, spices, etc.  

Loida has requested a loan for PHP 25000 through NWTF to purchase more items to sell such as sardines, groceries, etc in her sari-sari store.

In the future, Loida would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: purchase items to sell

loans.name: Zawadi

texts.en:
Zawadi is a married woman with eight children. Seven of the children attend school and one is still young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a business selling coconuts from home to her neighbors and passersby. In addition, she also sells groundnuts, which contributes to her other source of living. Zawadi faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the KSHS 10,000, she wants to pay school fees for her child. She decided to join Yehu to access loans and expand her business.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her child.

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
Julita, 37, is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Rogito, a salesman, and is the mother of four children. By the grace of God, Julita has managed to support her older children's schooling up to high school level. At this time, she is working hard to send her children to school. This is a dream for most poor Filipino parents like Julita as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Julita operates a bicycle parts business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers and sell them per item with a little profit. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 1000 in sales every day.

To help her continue her business operations, she is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Julita dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her inventory in her bicycle parts business.

loans.name: Nurgul

texts.en:
Women of Central Asian countries are mostly involved in several industries like textile, food production, medicine and teaching. A big portion is on behalf of trade. 

Nurgul, 43, has experience in borrowing loans because she started a business breeding and selling cattle in 1999 thanks to a loan borrowed from a local bank. Soon Nurgul purchased a small pavilion where she could promote and sell food products. She said that twelve years of experience in this business have taught her many lessons. Every day work and patience in the past do not allow her to make mistakes in the present. She shares her knowledge with younger generations, and it helps them not to repeat Nurgul’s mistakes. Her monthly income generated from selling food products comprises 39,000 soms. Nurgul plans to use these funds plus those acquired from Kiva lenders for investing in goods circulation and in a purchase of a house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
	
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more foodstuffs and ultimately purchase a house

loans.name: G.s. Guadalupe Group

texts.es: Lubys, Margarita y Lisset conforman al grupo solidario Guadalupe. Ambas tiene diferentes actividades económicas, Lisset Carolina tiene su negocio que es una pulpería. Hace más de 2 años que tiene esta actividad con mucho sacrificio y dedicación ella ha salido adelante el empeño que dedica todos los días es admirable pues la mayoría de sus clientes llegan en busca de los diferentes productos que ofrece. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de golosinas, granos básicos, detergentes, pan, enlatados y sopas.
texts.en:
Lubys, Margarita and Lisset are part of the Solidarity Group Guadalupe. They each have different businesses.  

Lisset Carolina runs a general store as her business.  She has worked at this for over 2 years and with a lot of sacrifice and dedication, she has done very well.  The hard work and effort she puts forth each day is admirable.  The majority of her customers come to her store looking for the variety of products she offers.

The loan she requests is for the purchase of snacks, staple foods, cleaning products, bread, canned goods, and soup.

loans.use: to purchase snacks, staple foods, cleaning products, bread, canned goods, and soup

loans.name: Pro Mujer J.p. Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “PRO MUJER J.P.” iniciará su primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Santiago II, está compuesta por seis integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva encabezada por la señora Elva. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: comercio, producción y servicio.

La señora Elva, indica que hace veinte y cinco años que trabaja con Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de amigas. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de muebles usados, que viene trabajando hace diez años atrás, implementando este negocio viendo la necesidad del mercado.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para aumentar su capital (compra de muebles usados), que comprara de la calle Final Castillo y lo comercializará en Av. Ballivián. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella es vuida y tiene cinco hijo.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta la capacitación, salud y la Asociación comunal.
texts.en:
The “Pro Mujer J.P.” communal bank is about to start its first loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Santiago II regional office.  It is comprised of six members.  It is run by a board of directors, which is led by Elva.  The businesses that the members of the group are engaged in are varied and include commerce, production, and service.

Elva points out that she has been working with Pro Mujer for 25 years.  She joined by invitation from her friends.  She currently has a business selling used furniture.  She has had this business for 10 years.  She started this business upon seeing the demand in the market.  

The loan that she will now get is to increase her capital (to buy used furniture).  She will buy on Final Castillo Street, and she will sell it at Avenida Ballivián.

This type of work allows her to generate resources in order to support her family as much as possible.  She is a widow, and she has five children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she said she likes the training, the health services, and the communal bank

loans.use: to buy furniture.

loans.name: Ganga

texts.en:
Ganga is 30 years-old .  She is married and has 2 children, ages 9 and 3.  In 2002, she established her grocery store business.  Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received, and successfully repaid, 5 loans from Patan BPW.  She used her most recent to increase inventory of the store.  In the future, Ganga plans to uplift the economic condition of her family.  She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy.  Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home.  Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins.  By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability.  While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

loans.use: to buy grocery goods for her shop

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is married with one daughter. She has a business selling women’s clothing in several markets of Kahovka and the Kherson region for 8 years.  Currently, she has over 23,500 Grivnas in turnover capital. Her net profit is about 4,500 Grivnas a month. 

Valentina is requesting a loan of 20,000 Grivnas to increase inventory in her kiosks. She is hoping to increase sales and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy more inventory for her women's clothing business.

loans.name: Elbis Israel

texts.es:
Don Elbis tiene 44 años de edad, vive junto a su esposa y sus tres hijos.

Él se dedica a amenizar eventos religiosos en las iglesias de las comunidades cercanas.Desde hace 8 años se dedica a este oficio, el cual aprendió de un primo. El ha comprado varios instrumentos musicales, para lo cual necesitaba un medio de transporte. Por este motivo solicitó un préstamo a Fundación Campo para comprar un microbús. Éste préstamo lo pagó de forma muy puntual.

Actualmente don Elbis solicita un  préstamo a Fundación Campo para construir un garaje para guardar su microbús, ya que en la noche él lo deja a la intemperie y corre el riesgo que se lo puedan robar. Con el préstamo  don Elbis estaría asegurando que su microbús este seguro, ya que a través de el se gana el sustento diario para su familia. De igual manera el no tendría que estar vigilando el microbus por las noches para que no le pasa nada.

Don Elbis espera que sus hijos sean unos profesionales, y espera con los ingresos que deje el microbús enviarlos a la escuela y poder comprar otro de año mas reciente.
texts.en:
Elbis is 44 years old and lives with his wife and three children.

He entertains at religious events in churches in nearby communities. He has provided this service, which he learned from a cousin, for eight years. He had bought various musical instruments for which he needed a means of transport. For this reason he requested a prior loan from Fundación Campo to buy a minibus. He repaid that loan very punctually.

Currently, Elbis is requesting a loan from Fundación Campo to build a garage in which to keep his minibus, since at night he leaves it in the open and it runs the risk of being stolen. With the loan, Elbis would insure that his minibus is safe, since he earns his daily living with it for his family. He would not have to keep checking on the minibus throughout the night to make sure it was safe.

Elbis hopes that his children will be professionals and he hopes to send them to school with income earned from the minibus. He also hopes to able to buy another newer one.

loans.use: to build a garage to keep his minibus in.

loans.name: Justina

texts.es: Justina de 49 años es una mujer sencilla y trabajadora vive en su propia casa junto a su esposo Domingo y sus 03 queridos hijos quienes le inspiran valor para seguir adelante y mantenerlos sano y salvo. Los verdes campos de su centro poblado de Palmapampa, ubicado en la selva tropical Ayacuchana, han sido en la vida de Justina un lugar agradable para trabajar y vivir junto a su familia. Desde muy pequeña sus padres le enseñaron esta labor y ahora tiene sus propias tierras, siendo su pareja quien más la apoya en éste trabajo. Justina cuida con mucho esmero sus plantas de cacao y Plátano y lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es cosechar, lleva 20 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es transportar lo cosechado hasta los centros de acopio situados en distintas ciudades de su región. Por tanto solicita el préstamo para ampliar la siembra con mas plantas de cacao ya que es una de las plantas que en menor tiempo brotan sus frutos. Este será su primer crédito y está muy contenta de saber que contará con su apoyo. Con los 1,500 nuevos soles, comprará semillas de cacao y así aumentar su producción.
texts.en:
49-year-old Justina is a humble and hard-working woman who lives in her own home together with her husband, Domingo, and their three beloved children who inspire her to get ahead in life and keep them safe and sound.

The green fields of her village of Palmapampa, located in the tropical rainforest of Ayacucho, have been a pleasant place for Justina as she has worked and lived there together with her family.  Her parents taught her how to farm when she was very young and she now has her own land.  It is her husband who supports her the most in her work.  Justina provides her cacao and banana plants with a lot of care and attention.  What she most enjoys about her work is harvesting her crops.  She has been in this business for 20 years and she considers the most difficult part of her work to be transporting her harvests to the warehouse centers located in the different towns in her region.  

Justina is requesting this loan so that she can sow more cacao plants as this is one of the plants which provides fruit in the least amount of time.  This will be Justina's third loan and she is very happy to know that she will have your support.  With her 1,500 soles, Justina will buy cacao seeds and thereby increase her production.

loans.use: to buy cacao seeds

loans.name: Otgonbileg

texts.en:
Otgonbileg is 52 years old and lives with her husband, two children and her granddaughter. Her husband is an accountant, her children are college students and her granddaughter stays at home. 

She started her grocery business in 1996 by planting potatoes. Now, she harvests 2,500 kgs. of potatoes each year and she owns a retailing counter in a local market. 

However, her own harvest isn't enough for running a retail business so she buys additional stocks each year. She is requesting 800,000 MNT to buy other kinds of vegetables for her grocery trading business.

loans.use: To buy other kinds of vegetables.

loans.name: Nassir

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 29 years old, married and a father to one child. 

Nassir has been a shop-owner since 2010, selling household items. He has sufficient experience in this field and a deep understanding of local consumer needs. His shop is situated in a crowded area so there are a good number of customers passing by.

He is requesting a $2400 loan in order to renovate his shop’s walls and floors, to make shelves and to add more inventories. He is aiming to gain more profits to offer him the opportunity to provide a better life for his family as a whole.

loans.use: in order to renovate his shop’s walls and floors, to make shelves and to add more inventories.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es:
La socia tiene 30 años de edad y es conviviente y tiene 3 hijos; La socia sigue teniendo su negocio de venta de desayunos como quinua con leche, manzana con leche, desayuno de maca,tortas,chocolate y sándwich de queso,ella vende en las mañanas en forma ambulatoria desde las 5:00 a.m hasta las 10:00 a.m,tambien se dedica al negocio de tejidos,ella realiza tejidos de lana como pantalones y chompas tanto para niños y adultos,por medio de este negocio la socia saca adelante a sus hijos,la socia quiere ampliar y mejorar sus negocios de venta de desayunos y venta de tejidos . La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar insumos para hacer desayunos y comprar lana para tejer los pantalones y chompas.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
 La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en: The member is 39 years old, living with a partner, and has 3 children. The member continues her business of selling breakfasts such as quinoa with milk, apples with milk, maca breakfasts, tortas, chocolate, and cheese sandwiches. She sells on foot from 5:00AM until 10:00AM in the mornings. She also has a textile business, weaving wool for pants and sweaters for children and adults. Through this business her children have prospered. The member wants to expand and improve her breakfast business and textile sales. She is asking for a loan in order to buy supplies to make breakfast and to buy wool to knit the pants and sweaters. The member is happy for the loan and she promises to make her payments on time.

loans.use: to buy supplies to make breakfasts to sell, and buy wool to knit pants and sweaters to sell.

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
Mary's group is comprised of three hardworking women. Mary is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. For the past year, Mary has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells products like sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Mary has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase supplies for resale, and will help Mary to generate greater profits and buy books for her young brothers. Mary hopes that in the future she will be able to become a musician. 

Mary is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Mary's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for resale.

loans.name: Josphine

texts.en:
Josphine used her first loan to buy more goats, which she reared and sold. 

She has applied for a second loan of KES 10,000, with which she will buy more goats to rear and sell later at a profit. 

She hopes to succeed in the future.

loans.use: To buy more goats for sale.

loans.name: Sharon Fe

texts.en:
Sharon Fe is a married woman with one child. She is 40 years old and resides in Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. 

Sharon Fe owns and operates a business venture, planting & harvesting decorative plants for sale to earn a living.  She's been in this business for 3 years. Each month, she earns PHP 6,000 doing this type of business. 

Sharon Fe requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.  She has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year.  In the future, she wants to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: buy seeds, seedlings & young crops

loans.name: Tawananyasha Group

texts.en: Greetings from Zimbabwe.  25 year old Progress is from Machipisa, Harare.  She is married with three children and two attending school.  Progress runs a retail business selling clothes.  The business has been in operation for two years.  She says the main challenge she faces is stiff competition.  Progress has requested a loan of $400.00 to buy clothes and shoes for resale.  She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve the general welfare of the family.  In the future, Progress plans to own a big shop selling a wide range of clothes and footwear.

loans.use: to buy clothes and footwear for resale.

loans.name: Josiane Yollande's Group

texts.fr: Responsable du groupe de deux personnes, Josiane vit avec son mari et a deux enfants. Elle est commerçante et a pour activité la vente de divers, mêches, cosmétiques et recharges au domicile de sa mère. Soucieuse de satisfaire les besoins de sa clientèle, elle a sollicité et obtenu un micro crédit à Finadev visant à maximiser ses intérêts, renforcer son fonds de commerce et à scolariser ses enfants.
texts.en:
Josiane is responsible for this two-person group. She lives with her husband and has two children. She's a merchant who sells various items, such as hair extensions, cosmetics, and refills, at her mother's home.

Eager to meet customer demand, she sought and obtained a loan from Kiva's partner, Finadev, in order to maximize her interests, bolster her working capital, and send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy 50 pieces of hair extension and 20 cosmetic products

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua is single and has no children.  Ekua sells onions at Mpredwow, which she has done for 2 years. She uses her income to pay the utility bills. She will use the loan to purchase more onions to sell. With the new profits from her business, Ekua will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more onions to sell.

loans.name: Phat's Group

texts.en: A villager from Moung Russey district of Battambang province, Phat is a married mother blessed with three schoolchildren and ages 44 years old. She secures the need in her household via rice farming. She has involved in current business for ages and it has returned her about 42,000 KHR per day. This is not the original loan for Pat with VisionFund(Kiva’s partner). She has repaid back her past loan completely and it has uplifted her lifestyle in a gradual pace. Now, she leads a group of two to get a new loan. As the leader, she will spend her entire loan portion to buy fertilizer, insecticide, and to pay for labor cost. She hopes that she can gain a good yield than before.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, insecticide, and to pay for labor cost

loans.name: Victor

texts.es: Es un señor trabajador, casado con 5 hijos en edad escolar. Pertenece a la etnia miskita del municipio de Puerto Cabezas. Desde hace más de dos décadas habita en una vivienda de tambo y madera. Solicita su primer financiamiento para cambiar la madera. Con el préstamo comprara materiales de construcción: madera, clavos y zinc. Él sueña con brindarle a su familia una vivienda con las condiciones adecuadas.

loans.use: para cambiar la madera de su casa de tambo

loans.name: Pendy Ann

texts.en:
As a married mother of seven children, Pendy Ann works hard to support her family.

She has a restaurant business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from fruit vending. Pendy Ann is borrowing PHP 7,000 through NWTF in order to buy additional utensils and ingredients for her restaurant business.

She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional utensils and ingredients for her restaurant business.

loans.name: Cheorn

texts.en:
M. Cheorn is a 53 year old single mother and grandmother. Her two sons, one daughter-in-law and two granddaughters all live in her home. M. Cheorn runs a small food stand selling rice, sugar palm, and papaya. She earns about $16.75 a day from her sales. 

M. Cheorn is requesting a loan of $750 to expand her business. She would like to purchase $500 worth of additional rice, $125 worth of additional sugar palm, and $125 worth of additional papaya. This is M. Cheorn\'s third loan with CREDIT, and she did not have trouble repaying on her previous loans. She is happy about the possibility of expanding her business so that she can better provide for her growing family.

loans.use: Purchase more rice, sugar palm, and papaya.

loans.name: Amisi

texts.en:
Amisi B. is a very active member of Life in Africa. He joined in 2004 as a member. Since then, he has been so dedicated and hard-working. He has been quick to participate in community initiatives and has learned how to make hand crafts such as banana fibered balls, bracelets out of organic materials, and many other things. Among the things he likes is serving God. He is somebody who is helpful to the community, often translating at meetings into the Luganda language for other members who don't understand English.

Since the loan scheme began in Life in Africa, he has never rushed but has been very active at the loan review meetings to learn how to make a good loan plan. His plan is to purchase one public pay phone.

Once his loan request is accepted and funded, he will locate his business at Ntinda stage, where there are a large number of public pay phone users. To compete with his counter-parts, he is not going to charge as much. He has learned that all the public pay phone attendants charge 300 Uganda shillings (UGX) for mtn to mtn network per 56 seconds and across other networks for 400 -500 per 56 sec. Amisi plans to charge 200 UGX and 300 UGX for these services instead. He has a brother willing to operate the phone and expects to make a monthly profit of 60,000 UGX after paying his brother.

He is seeking a loan amount of two hundred and fifty thousand shillings, and he will repay the loan in 12 months. (1 USD = 1,722 UGX) Below is his budget:

Purchase of one public pay phone @ ...... 200,000 UGX

Ground rent for four months @ 10,000 UGX per month.....40,000 UGX

Stool for putting the phones................10,000 UGX

Total 250,000 UGX

loans.use: Purchase of pay phone

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase and sell clothing

loans.name: Chun

texts.en:
Mr. Chun C. is 40 years old and calls Phnom Penh, Cambodia his home. He is a motor-taxi driver and his wife takes care of their three children.

Mr. Chun C. would like to purchase a motorcycle to continue his business. Currently, his motorcycle is wearing down and may not last much longer to allow him to continue to work as a motor-taxi driver. With a loan of $700, he hopes to be able to purchase a new motorcycle.

In the future, they aspire to their own grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Muhamed
