texts.en: Muhamed J. is forty-five years old and has a wife and four children.  He buys sheep, fattens them, and then sells them at a higher price after three months.  With his previous loans he managed to increase the number of sheep by four.  He says his plan is to increase the number of sheep for a better profit and to purchase cows for the family one at a time. He is requesting $175 to purchase three lambs and one calf.

loans.use: Purchase additional livestock for fattening

loans.name: Faaafe

texts.en: Faaafe is 49 years of age and has 4 children. She is started the borrowing centre in February in the village of Samusu. Her first loan of 750.00 Tala ($300.00 US) was used to buy chemicals for her three acre taro plantation quite far from her house. She used to go to the market twice a week where she earned 200.00-300.00 Tala ($80-120 US). She is applying for another 1250.00 Tala ($500.00 US) loan to extend her taro plantation and to help out with her family remittances.

loans.use: To buy supplies and equipment for her plantation

loans.name: Kamal

texts.en: Kamal is a 41 year old father of 3 who lives and works in the Bekaa region of Lebanon. Kamal owns a pharmacy which is the main source of income for his family. He needs a loan to buy more merchandise for the store. This will be  Kamal's 7th loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To buy supplies for his pharmacy.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mrs. Mary E. is 32 years old and married with five children. She lives in Benin City and sells electrical materials. She is seeking the loan of $875 to enable her to buy more electrical materials. She learned the business from her husband and started her operation in 1997.

loans.use: To buy electrical materials for sale

loans.name: Encum

texts.en: Encum is 43, married, and a mother of five children. She has a food stall in front of her house where she sells snacks, flavoured ices, fried snacks, and other food items. She earns $3.00 a day. Her husband has no fixed job so she must work hard to support the entire family. She will use this loan to expand her business.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Khotam

texts.en:
Khotam is 43 years old and is married with four children. He is a jack of all trades in the sphere of construction and repair. Khotam works as a foreman on a team that provides minor and major repairs of houses and apartments. At the same time, he is a very good carpenter. Khotam dreams of providing a higher education for all of his four sons. Moreover in Tajikistan there is a tradition that a father has to build a house for each of his sons. Knowing all this, Khotam is working really hard to make the business successful and generate a stable income for his large family.

Khotam now plans to purchase construction equipment. This loan is his first. Khotam promises to work harder to be able to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: Purchasing of the construction equipment.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
The beautiful color display in Juliet O.’s shop makes her shop stand out from other shops in the locality. Her wares range from clothes, to handbags and jewelry. Juliet is a single woman and she is 29 years of age. Her aim is to improve her business, which will, in turn, increase her profit. She lives in Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria and has been in business since 1999.

Juliet needs a loan of $875 to buy more shoes, clothes and bags to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more clothes, bags and shoes

loans.name: Cristo Vive Group

texts.en:
Paulina R. is a dedicated and vivacious woman who lives with her 4 children (ages: 16, 14, 12, 3) in San Pedro de Macoris. Currently, Paulina sells shoes and slippers by walking around her community all throughout the day. She will use this loan to continue making small improvements to her business by purchasing better quality items and developing a consistent client base. Her goal for the future is to open a proper store in her neighborhood so that she doesn’t have to walk from place to place every day. She told us that it is very hard on her knees and back to carry around her merchandise for 10 hours every day. Paulina wants to use any extra profit from her business to help her children with school and necessities.

On behalf of Esperanza, thank your for your generous support and we look forward in joining with you to watch these women succeed! God Bless.

loans.use: To buy more shoes and slippers.

loans.name: Lobanok South 2006-2 Group

texts.en:
Lina M., the group leader, currently runs a hotel and has requested this loan in order to expand her business. Lina is 31 years old, married, and has three children between the ages of 2 and 8. Her husband is a security guard and her children go to school. Each week, Lina makes approximately 240 Sudanese pounds in profits.

Lina is joined in her small group by Elizabeth Foni, Asunta W., M. L., and L. W.. Elizabeth Foni sells beer at a bar and wants to expand her business. Asunta W. currently sells bread at the market and would use this loan to build a bakery. M. L. has a business selling vegetables and hopes to open up a shop. L. W. sells alcohol but would use the loan to pay school fees.

loans.use: To expand a hotel

loans.name: Muta

texts.en:
Muta P., 35, is married with 3 children. She has many years of experience in the taro and banana business. She sells to friends, relatives,and the local community; also in harvest season they supply the public market 3 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~104 USD).

SPBD loans are Muta’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.The loan will also support her children's school fees and her church contribution. Her husband is self employed and works to maintain the business.

loans.use: Purchase gromozone chemicals, sting chemicals, weedkiller sprayer machine, shovel, bushknife, and wire for fence

loans.name: Mbène

texts.fr:
Mbène S. is a married woman raising 4 children. She has been a member of the village bank of Santhiaba Mosquée for 6 and a half years. Her business consists in buying and re-selling beads, costume jewelry, and small “pagnes” (lengths of African print cloth). She wants to bolster her business to improve the living conditions and health of her family. The loan she is requesting will be reimbursed in one single payment at the end of 6 months.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Mbène S. est une femme mariée avec 04 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du banc villageois de Santhiaba Mosquée depuis 6 ans et demi. Son activité consiste à acheter et revendre des perles, des bijoux et de petits pagnes. Elle veut renforcer son commerce pour améliorer les conditions de vie et de santé de sa famille. Le prêt qu'elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use:
Buying and re-selling beads, costume jewelry, and small "pagnes"

Acheter et revendre des perles, bijoux et petits pagnes

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana D. is divorced and has two kids. She lives with her family in Dunkwa, a suburb of Obuasi in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She is 43 years old. She runs a clothing shop and has been selling jeans, blouses and skirts, women's slippers, and dressing bags for the past seven years.

Diana is constrained by insufficient funds to run her business. She needs this loan to inject more working capital into the business to scale up her business progress. She believes the loan will help her have resources to purchase good quality and large quantity to upgrade her inventory. She says she would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To purchase jeans, ladies' wear, and slippers

loans.name: Launiu

texts.en:
Launiu M., 34, is married with four children. She has five years of experience in the vegetable garden business. She sells to the village people four days per week. 

She has one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~$187 USD). SPBD loans are Launiu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. 

She will use the loan to buy the equipment used in her business. Her husband and children help out.

loans.use: To buy materials and equipment used for her vegetable business

loans.name: Zuwena

texts.en:
Zuwena R. has been selling juices and clothes in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for six years. She works from 6:00 am to 8:00 pm every day and earns a profit of approximately $85 each month. She has previously taken out one loan from BRAC Tanzania, which she repaid successfully and on time. She is requesting her second loan so that she can further increase her inventory.

Zuwena is 38 years old, married, and has four children, aged 4, 8, 14, and 15.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and juices to sell

loans.name: Gideon

texts.en:
Gideon A.–Adjei is 26 years old and not yet married. He is in the business of photography. 

He has a small studio where he works and also travels to places to capture videos and pictures of clients who ask for his services. He uses materials such as cameras, film, glass to frame pictures, etc.

Gideon says he has been in this business for only one year. However, he has made a lot of economic gains through this venture. He says he wants a loan to help him expand and decorate his studio, and also buy the materials he uses to work. 

Gideon belongs to the “Victory Group” which is made up of only five members. The group members guarantee one another as collateral to access the loan.

loans.use: To expand his photography business

loans.name: Mrs. Sokha Kong Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nine people in Svay Chek village in Kampong Chhnang province form this village bank and Mrs. Sokha K. is the bank president. She is a rice middleman who buys rice to keep in stock and then resell later at a better price. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. She thus decided to ask for a loan to add to her capital and buy more rice for her current business.

Her husband, Mr. Sok Thouch, is a bicycle repairer. Mrs. Sokha K. is 42 years old and the mother of two children who are enrolled in the local school.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Eight members have end-of-term loan and the rest of have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more rice to keep in stock and resell later at a better price.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima is a 52 year old woman who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon, with her husband and their four children. Fatima has been working as a sewer since 1988. Fatima is good at sewing and her clients are her friends and neighbors. In the future, she plans to increase her business.  She has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua purchase thread and repair her car.  This is the first time that Fatima has requested a loan.

loans.use: To purchase thread and repair her car.

loans.name: Honronya (La Dignité) Group

texts.fr:
Parmi les quatre femmes du groupe Honronya  trois  sont mariées et une est veuve, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 26 ans et 2 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier lafiala de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). 
Elles se sont  connues à  travers des liens   de voisinage et pour la pratique de la même activité à savoir l’activité de fabrication et vente du savon. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité et jouissent d’une réputation sans égale.
 Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de leur clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Honronya a décidé d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son quatrième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des barils  de déchets d’huile et de  la soude caustique. Le savon ainsi fabriqué   est vendu en gros et en détail, au comptant où à crédit au marché de Koutiala et dans les foires des villages environnants.
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 200 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier et d’ouvrir d’un atelier moderne de fabrication de savons.
texts.en:
Among the four women of the group Honronya, three are married and one is a widow. They average 26 years of age and two children and live in large traditional extended families in the Lafiala district of the city of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They know one another through community ties and through work in almost the same business, namely making and selling soap. The women are in high demand in this field of work and enjoy an unparalleled reputation.

In order to satisfy their ever-increasing number of customers, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their fourth solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

They plan to use this loan for buying barrels of waste oil and caustic soda. The soap thus made is then sold wholesale and retail, cash or credit accepted, at the Koutiala marketplace and at the fairs of surrounding villages.

They each hope to realize an average profit of 200,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The funds will be used to pay the loan interest, to provide for the extended family, and to invest the rest in businesses. Their ambition is to diversify and to open a modern workshop for making soap.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy waste oil and caustic soda

loans.name: Saing

texts.en:
Saing K., a 26-year-old farmer in Pursat Province, is married to Neoun, 22, who earns a living raising piglets behind the house. A responsible father and neighbor, Saing harvests his crop twice a year and sells to customers in bulk at a good price.

He would like to end his reliance on his neighbor's oxen to plow his field, and so is requesting a loan of $250 to buy oxen and to renovate his house. The loan will help the family achieve a better living standard.

loans.use: To buy oxen and to renovate his house.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita is 49 years old and married with six children. She sells eggs. Rita needs the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more eggs to sell. She is happy with LAPO Microfinance and Kiva, She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more eggs to sell

loans.name: Orl

texts.en:
Mr. Orl A., 33, makes a living by buying and selling motorbikes. He normally purchases the motorbikes to paint them and resell them to gain income. Beside this, he is also a local construction foreman. He is married to Sroy, 34, a good housewife who cares for the children and cooks tasty meals for the family. The couple has two young children who are enrolled in the primary school.

To enlarge the business and to earn additional income, A. is applying for a loan to add to his existing capital. He will use the money to buy more motorcycles to resell to gain income and to buy a cow from a farmer to raise and sell its offspring.

loans.use: To buy more motorcycles to resell and a cow

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en: Mrs. Teresa P. is 32 years of age, married, and is a bona fide resident of Dipolog City. She is blessed with 3 children, all of whom are still studying. She has been an active member of Paglaum MPC for 3 years and already has had several loans that have financed her farming activities. She is busy with her banana plantation, corn, root crops, and vegetables. These crops are all in their yard, cultivated and managed both by Theresa and her husband. Now she has requested another loan from the Paglaum MPC intended for repair of their house to have comfortable shelter for the family. The loan shall be paid out from the yield income of their farm.

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials and labor to repair home.

loans.name: Elizardo Perez Group

texts.es:
Doce personas conforman la asociación “Elizardo Pérez”, trabajan junto a la familia de Pro-Mujer  hace tres años en el centro focal Alto Lima ubicado  en la zona 16 de julio de la ciudad de El Alto.
Varias son las actividades que realiza este grupo algunas se dedican a la costura; otras realizan tejidos en maquina; venden pantalones  deportivos; chompas tejidas a mano; chamarras,  también otras se dedican a la carpintería.
La asociación Luz y Vida afirma que necesitan generar mayores ingresos, ya que lo que obtienen no les alcanza para mantener económicamente a sus familias, para esto necesitan de créditos para comprar mercadería en mayor cantidad.
texts.en:
Twelve people make up the "Elizardo P." group. They have been working alongside the Pro-Mujer family for three years at the focal point Alto Lima located in the July 16 area of the city of El Alto. This group engages in several activities such as sewing, weaving by machine, selling sports pants, hand-woven sweaters, jackets and others are engaged in carpentry. The group Luz y Vida affirms that it needs to generate more income, because what the members earn is not enough to support their families economically. This is why they need this loan to purchase merchandise in larger quantities.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise in larger quantities.

loans.name: Dalerjon

texts.en:
O. Dalerjon is 30 years old. He is married with 3 children. For more than 10 years, Dalerjon have been working at baking “lepeshka”- the national bread. He believes that this business is profitable and is not subject to seasonality. He gets up early and bakes the lepeshka and other breads so that people have fresh bread on their tables for breakfast.

All the input materials like flour, salt, and yeast he purchases at the local market. Now, due to high demand, Dalerjon wants to increase the amount of bread he produces so that he requests a loan of 800 US Dollars. The loan will be spent for purchasing flour and coal for baking the “lepeshka”. Dalerjon deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing flour wholesale

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama S. is 44 years old. She is married and has four children—a son and three daughters. One is in the university and the others are in junior high and primary school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in Dwenase, a commercial town in the Western Region and a suburb of Sefwi-Wiawso. Ama is a hard working woman. Her husband works with a timber firm. She sells groceries such as Milo, sugar, rice, candies, bread, and so forth in a store on the street. Ama has been in business for 12 years and wants a loan to buy more provisions to expand her business. She is hopeful to improve upon her standard of living and give all her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy provisions

loans.name: Raisa

texts.en:
Raisa, as the business owner, knows that the success of her clothing business will in large part depend on the selection of her merchandise. She is also aware that it is best to keep an open mind and to be receptive to customer suggestions. Her maternity clothing store may initially focus on casual wear, but she may find that she has a lot of working women clamoring for suits tailored for pregnant women. Raisa has been in this business for many years, and she has succeeded in attracting customers who trust her. 

She requested a loan to increase her stock of goods.

loans.use: To increase her stock of goods.

loans.name: Nicolaza

texts.es:
Ninolaza es socia del Bancomunal Siempre Juntas.
Nicolaza es  casada tiene 55 años, tiene tres hijos que son mayores y trabajan. 
Nicolaza es de puno en su tierra se dedicaba a cuidar ganado, cuando llego a Lima a los 30 años se caso desde entonces se puso a vender tubérculos y verduras  en un puesto que alquilo el mercado de Pamplona Baja, con la ayuda de su hija., 
Desde que Nicolaza está en Finca su capital ha crecido y tiene muchas ideas de negocio..
Incolaza necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles, para comprar diferentes variedades de papa por saco, limos por saco, cajones de tomate y paquetes de verduras.
El sueño de Nicolaza es poner otros puestos de verduras en otros mercados.
texts.en:
Nicolaza is a member of the Always Together (Siempre Juntas) Community Bank. She is 55 years old, is married, and has three children, who are adults and are working. Nicolaza is from Puno, where she raised livestock. She came to Lima when she was 30 years old, when she got married. Since then she has sold tubers and vegetables in a stand that she rents in the Pamplona Baja Market, with the help of her daughter. Since Nicolaza has been with Finca, her capital has grown and she has many ideas for her business. Nicolaza needs a loan for 3000 soles to buy different varieties of sacks of potatoes, sacks of limes, boxes of tomatoes and packets of vegetables. Nicolaza’s dream is to have other vegetable stands in other markets.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy different varieties of potatoes

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah is a 43-year-old single mother of five children aged between 9 and 27 years. Three of her children go to school. She resides in and owns a one-roomed house where she lives with six people. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day.

Norah resides and works in an urban area selling handicrafts like table cloths and knitted sweaters in Mukwano Arcade, one of Kampala’s streets. She uses public transport to and from home and work. Norah sells to an average of ten people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent and feeding the family.

Norah has been in her business for the last ten years and has been with MCDT for seven years. She is servicing her twentieth loan, working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more thread and rolls of cloth. Norah is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and to owning a permanent home.

loans.use: To buy more thread and rolls of cloth

loans.name: So Khou

texts.en: Mrs. So Khou N. lives in Phnum Lorn Tes village in Takeo province. She is a duck breeder who also collects the duck eggs to sell. Since her poultry business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing 160 more ducks for breeding, to earn income. Her husband, Mr. Prum Lean, is a farmer who owns a piece of land for cultivating rice. Mrs. So Khou N. is 49 years old and the mother of six children. One of her children is employed in a Casino Club while another is an electrician. The other children are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy 160 more ducks for breeding to earn income.

loans.name: Tetyana

texts.en:
Tetyana G. is divorced. She raises her teenage daughter herself. Tetyana runs a small enterprise selling men’s footwear in the central marketplace of Belaya Tserkov. Tetyana started her small business 12 years ago. Presently, she has about 21,000 UAH invested in inventory. Her profit amounts to 7,000 UAH a month.

Tetyana is requesting a loan of 10,000 UAH to purchase additional seasonal merchandise and increase her working capital as a result. Tetyana is hoping to see her business flourish in the future, bringing her stable income so that she can pay her daughter’s college fee.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Nemi

texts.en:
Nemi F. is 58 years old and already a widower. His wife died after giving birth to their daughter named Czarina Ellen who is still studying.  They are living in the village of Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is a vocational graduate of Driving Mechanics. After this, He is doing everything in order to support the education of his daughter. 

Farming is his major source of income.  He cultivates their farm twice a year by planting rice and corn. But since it is only seasonal. he then ventured to another business to have an alternative source of income.  Through his tricycle operation business, he was able to provide their basic needs and send his daughter to school. During harvest season, he can to earn an income of PHP15,000.00 and PHP2,500.00 a month from his tricycle. He utilized his income by acquiring their daily basic needs, finance the tuition fees and allowances of his daughter. 

To further maintain his two businesses, he is now asking to avail a loan of PHP7,000 that he can use for the maintenance of his tricycle and also to purchase their farming needs.  He believes that someday, his daughter will finished her studies and their status of living will improve also through the financial assistance of the KIVA lenders.

loans.use: For the  maintenance of his tricycle transport business and farming needs
